Parsing [sent. 8801 len. 57]: But Mrs Skewton tried it on with mincing satisfaction ; smirked at her cadaverous self in the glass , as she thought of its killing effect upon the Major ; and suffering her maid to take it off again , and to prepare her for repose , tumbled into ruins like a house of painted cards .
Parsing [sent. 8802 len. 16]: All this time , Edith remained at the dark window looking out into the street .
Parsing [sent. 8803 len. 28]: When she and her mother were at last left alone , she moved from it for the first time that evening , and came opposite to her .
Parsing [sent. 8804 len. 51]: The yawning , shaking , peevish figure of the mother , with her eyes raised to confront the proud erect form of the daughter , whose glance of fire was bent downward upon her , had a conscious air upon it , that no levity or temper could conceal . '
Parsing [sent. 8805 len. 10]: I am tired to death , ' said she .
Parsing [sent. 8806 len. 10]: ` You ca n't be trusted for a moment .
Parsing [sent. 8807 len. 7]: You are worse than a child .
Parsing [sent. 8808 len. 2]: Child !
Parsing [sent. 8809 len. 11]: No child would be half so obstinate and undutiful . '
Parsing [sent. 8810 len. 27]: ` Listen to me , mother , ' returned Edith , passing these words by with a scorn that would not descend to trifle with them .
Parsing [sent. 8811 len. 11]: ` You must remain alone here until I return . '
Parsing [sent. 8812 len. 13]: ` Must remain alone here , Edith , until you return ! '
Parsing [sent. 8813 len. 4]: repeated her mother .
Parsing [sent. 8814 len. 38]: ` Or in that name upon which I shall call to-morrow to witness what I do , so falsely : and so shamefully , I swear I will refuse the hand of this man in the church .
Parsing [sent. 8815 len. 14]: If I do not , may I fall dead upon the pavement ! '
Parsing [sent. 8816 len. 20]: The mother answered with a look of quick alarm , in no degree diminished by the look she met .
Parsing [sent. 8817 len. 19]: ` It is enough , ' said Edith , steadily , ` that we are what we are .
Parsing [sent. 8818 len. 13]: I will have no youth and truth dragged down to my level .
Parsing [sent. 8819 len. 23]: I will have no guileless nature undermined , corrupted , and perverted , to amuse the leisure of a world of mothers .
Parsing [sent. 8820 len. 5]: You know my meaning .
Parsing [sent. 8821 len. 6]: Florence must go home . '
Parsing [sent. 8822 len. 14]: ` You are an idiot , Edith , ' cried her angry mother .
Parsing [sent. 8823 len. 24]: ` Do you expect there can ever be peace for you in that house , till she is married , and away ? '
Parsing [sent. 8824 len. 29]: ` Ask me , or ask yourself , if I ever expect peace in that house , ' said her daughter , ` and you know the answer .
Parsing [sent. 8825 len. 69]: ` And am I to be told to-night , after all my pains and labour , and when you are going , through me , to be rendered independent , ' her mother almost shrieked in her passion , while her palsied head shook like a leaf , ` that there is corruption and contagion in me , and that I am not fit company for a girl !
Parsing [sent. 8826 len. 6]: What are you , pray ?
Parsing [sent. 8827 len. 6]: What are you ? ' '
Parsing [sent. 8828 len. 56]: I have put the question to myself , ' said Edith , ashy pale , and pointing to the window , ` more than once when I have been sitting there , and something in the faded likeness of my sex has wandered past outside ; and God knows I have met with my reply .
Parsing [sent. 8829 len. 36]: Oh mother , mother , if you had but left me to my natural heart when I too was a girl -- a younger girl than Florence -- how different I might have been ! '
Parsing [sent. 8830 len. 66]: Sensible that any show of anger was useless here , her mother restrained herself , and fell a whimpering , and bewailed that she had lived too long , and that her only child had cast her off , and that duty towards parents was forgotten in these evil days , and that she had heard unnatural taunts , and cared for life no longer .
Parsing [sent. 8831 len. 42]: ` If one is to go on living through continual scenes like this , ' she whined , ' I am sure it would be much better for me to think of some means of putting an end to my existence .
Parsing [sent. 8832 len. 2]: Oh !
Parsing [sent. 8833 len. 19]: The idea of your being my daughter , Edith , and addressing me in such a strain ! '
Parsing [sent. 8834 len. 21]: ` Between us , mother , ' returned Edith , mournfully , ` the time for mutual reproaches is past .
Parsing [sent. 8835 len. 9]: ` Then why do you revive it ? '
Parsing [sent. 8836 len. 4]: whimpered her mother .
Parsing [sent. 8837 len. 13]: ` You know that you are lacerating me in the cruellest manner .
Parsing [sent. 8838 len. 9]: You know how sensitive I am to unkindness .
Parsing [sent. 8839 len. 27]: At such a moment , too , when I have so much to think of , and am naturally anxious to appear to the best advantage !
Parsing [sent. 8840 len. 7]: I wonder at you , Edith .
Parsing [sent. 8841 len. 11]: To make your mother a fright upon your wedding-day ! '
Parsing [sent. 8842 len. 49]: Edith bent the same fixed look upon her , as she sobbed and rubbed her eyes ; and said in the same low steady voice , which had neither risen nor fallen since she first addressed her , ' I have said that Florence must go home . '
Parsing [sent. 8843 len. 6]: ` Let her go ! '
Parsing [sent. 8844 len. 10]: cried the afflicted and affrighted parent , hastily . '
Parsing [sent. 8845 len. 10]: I am sure I am willing she should go .
Parsing [sent. 8846 len. 8]: What is the girl to me ? '
Parsing [sent. 8847 len. 60]: ` She is so much to me , that rather than communicate , or suffer to be communicated to her , one grain of the evil that is in my breast , mother , I would renounce you , as I would -LRB- if you gave me cause -RRB- renounce him in the church to-morrow , ' replied Edith .
Parsing [sent. 8848 len. 5]: ` Leave her alone .
Parsing [sent. 8849 len. 21]: She shall not , while I can interpose , be tampered with and tainted by the lessons I have learned .
Parsing [sent. 8850 len. 11]: This is no hard condition on this bitter night . '
Parsing [sent. 8851 len. 26]: ` If you had proposed it in a filial manner , Edith , ' whined her mother , ` perhaps not ; very likely not .
Parsing [sent. 8852 len. 23]: But such extremely cutting words -- ' ` They are past and at an end between us now , ' said Edith .
Parsing [sent. 8853 len. 35]: ` Take your own way , mother ; share as you please in what you have gained ; spend , enjoy , make much of it ; and be as happy as you will .
Parsing [sent. 8854 len. 8]: The object of our lives is won .
Parsing [sent. 8855 len. 7]: Henceforth let us wear it silently .
Parsing [sent. 8856 len. 11]: My lips are closed upon the past from this hour .
Parsing [sent. 8857 len. 10]: I forgive you your part in to-morrow 's wickedness .
Parsing [sent. 8858 len. 7]: May God forgive my own ! '
Parsing [sent. 8859 len. 40]: Without a tremor in her voice , or frame , and passing onward with a foot that set itself upon the neck of every soft emotion , she bade her mother good-night , and repaired to her own room .
Parsing [sent. 8860 len. 114]: But not to rest ; for there was no rest in the tumult of her agitation when alone to and fro , and to and fro , and to and fro again , five hundred times , among the splendid preparations for her adornment on the morrow ; with her dark hair shaken down , her dark eyes flashing with a raging light , her broad white bosom red with the cruel grasp of the relentless hand with which she spurned it from her , pacing up and down with an averted head , as if she would avoid the sight of her own fair person , and divorce herself from its companionship .
Parsing [sent. 8861 len. 32]: Thus , In the dead time of the night before her bridal , Edith Granger wrestled with her unquiet spirit , tearless , friendless , silent , proud , and uncomplaining .
Parsing [sent. 8862 len. 19]: At length it happened that she touched the open door which led into the room where Florence lay .
Parsing [sent. 8863 len. 9]: She started , stopped , and looked in .
Parsing [sent. 8864 len. 21]: A light was burning there , and showed her Florence in her bloom of innocence and beauty , fast asleep .
Parsing [sent. 8865 len. 13]: Edith held her breath , and felt herself drawn on towards her .
Parsing [sent. 8866 len. 41]: Drawn nearer , nearer , nearer yet ; at last , drawn so near , that stooping down , she pressed her lips to the gentle hand that lay outside the bed , and put it softly to her neck .
Parsing [sent. 8867 len. 14]: Its touch was like the prophet 's rod of old upon the rock .
Parsing [sent. 8868 len. 29]: Her tears sprung forth beneath it , as she sunk upon her knees , and laid her aching head and streaming hair upon the pillow by its side .
Parsing [sent. 8869 len. 10]: Thus Edith Granger passed the night before her bridal .
Parsing [sent. 8870 len. 10]: Thus the sun found her on her bridal morning .
Parsing [sent. 8871 len. 3]: CHAPTER 31 .
Parsing [sent. 8872 len. 33]: The Wedding Dawn with its passionless blank face , steals shivering to the church beneath which lies the dust of little Paul and his mother , and looks in at the windows .
Parsing [sent. 8873 len. 6]: It is cold and dark .
Parsing [sent. 8874 len. 23]: Night crouches yet , upon the pavement , and broods , sombre and heavy , in nooks and corners of the building .
Parsing [sent. 8875 len. 70]: The steeple-clock , perched up above the houses , emerging from beneath another of the countless ripples in the tide of time that regularly roll and break on the eternal shore , is greyly visible , like a stone beacon , recording how the sea flows on ; but within doors , dawn , at first , can only peep at night , and see that it is there .
Parsing [sent. 8876 len. 45]: Hovering feebly round the church , and looking in , dawn moans and weeps for its short reign , and its tears trickle on the window-glass , and the trees against the church-wall bow their heads , and wring their many hands in sympathy .
Parsing [sent. 8877 len. 27]: Night , growing pale before it , gradually fades out of the church , but lingers in the vaults below , and sits upon the coffins .
Parsing [sent. 8878 len. 72]: And now comes bright day , burnishing the steeple-clock , and reddening the spire , and drying up the tears of dawn , and stifling its complaining ; and the dawn , following the night , and chasing it from its last refuge , shrinks into the vaults itself and hides , with a frightened face , among the dead , until night returns , refreshed , to drive it out .
Parsing [sent. 8879 len. 56]: And now , the mice , who have been busier with the prayer-books than their proper owners , and with the hassocks , more worn by their little teeth than by human knees , hide their bright eyes in their holes , and gather close together in affright at the resounding clashing of the church-door .
Parsing [sent. 8880 len. 67]: For the beadle , that man of power , comes early this morning with the sexton ; and Mrs Miff , the wheezy little pew-opener -- a mighty dry old lady , sparely dressed , with not an inch of fulness anywhere about her -- is also here , and has been waiting at the church-gate half-an-hour , as her place is , for the beadle .
Parsing [sent. 8881 len. 22]: A vinegary face has Mrs Miff , and a mortified bonnet , and eke a thirsty soul for sixpences and shillings .
Parsing [sent. 8882 len. 45]: Beckoning to stray people to come into pews , has given Mrs Miff an air of mystery ; and there is reservation in the eye of Mrs Miff , as always knowing of a softer seat , but having her suspicions of the fee .
Parsing [sent. 8883 len. 28]: There is no such fact as Mr Miff , nor has there been , these twenty years , and Mrs Miff would rather not allude to him .
Parsing [sent. 8884 len. 34]: He held some bad opinions , it would seem , about free seats ; and though Mrs Miff hopes he may be gone upwards , she could n't positively undertake to say so .
Parsing [sent. 8885 len. 40]: Busy is Mrs Miff this morning at the church-door , beating and dusting the altar-cloth , the carpet , and the cushions ; and much has Mrs Miff to say , about the wedding they are going to have .
Parsing [sent. 8886 len. 49]: Mrs Miff is told , that the new furniture and alterations in the house cost full five thousand pound if they cost a penny ; and Mrs Miff has heard , upon the best authority , that the lady has n't got a sixpence wherewithal to bless herself .
Parsing [sent. 8887 len. 51]: Mrs Miff remembers , like wise , as if it had happened yesterday , the first wife 's funeral , and then the christening , and then the other funeral ; and Mrs Miff says , by-the-bye she 'll soap-and-water that ` ere tablet presently , against the company arrive .
Parsing [sent. 8888 len. 61]: Mr Sownds the Beadle , who is sitting in the sun upon the church steps all this time -LRB- and seldom does anything else , except , in cold weather , sitting by the fire -RRB- , approves of Mrs Miff 's discourse , and asks if Mrs Miff has heard it said , that the lady is uncommon handsome ?
Parsing [sent. 8889 len. 70]: The information Mrs Miff has received , being of this nature , Mr Sownds the Beadle , who , though orthodox and corpulent , is still an admirer of female beauty , observes , with unction , yes , he hears she is a spanker - an expression that seems somewhat forcible to Mrs Miff , or would , from any lips but those of Mr Sownds the Beadle .
Parsing [sent. 8890 len. 48]: In Mr Dombey 's house , at this same time , there is great stir and bustle , more especially among the women : not one of whom has had a wink of sleep since four o'clock , and all of whom were fully dressed before six .
Parsing [sent. 8891 len. 42]: Mr Towlinson is an object of greater consideration than usual to the housemaid , and the cook says at breakfast time that one wedding makes many , which the housemaid ca n't believe , and do n't think true at all .
Parsing [sent. 8892 len. 50]: Mr Towlinson reserves his sentiments on this question ; being rendered something gloomy by the engagement of a foreigner with whiskers -LRB- Mr Towlinson is whiskerless himself -RRB- , who has been hired to accompany the happy pair to Paris , and who is busy packing the new chariot .
Parsing [sent. 8893 len. 56]: In respect of this personage , Mr Towlinson admits , presently , that he never knew of any good that ever come of foreigners ; and being charged by the ladies with prejudice , says , look at Bonaparte who was at the head of 'em , and see what he was always up to !
Parsing [sent. 8894 len. 8]: Which the housemaid says is very true .
Parsing [sent. 8895 len. 25]: The pastry-cook is hard at work in the funereal room in Brook Street , and the very tall young men are busy looking on .
Parsing [sent. 8896 len. 34]: One of the very tall young men already smells of sherry , and his eyes have a tendency to become fixed in his head , and to stare at objects without seeing them .
Parsing [sent. 8897 len. 25]: The very tall young man is conscious of this failing in himself ; and informs his comrade that it 's his ` exciseman . '
Parsing [sent. 8898 len. 15]: The very tall young man would say excitement , but his speech is hazy .
Parsing [sent. 8899 len. 26]: The men who play the bells have got scent of the marriage ; and the marrow-bones and cleavers too ; and a brass band too .
Parsing [sent. 8900 len. 75]: The first , are practising in a back settlement near Battlebridge ; the second , put themselves in communication , through their chief , with Mr Towlinson , to whom they offer terms to be bought off ; and the third , in the person of an artful trombone , lurks and dodges round the corner , waiting for some traitor tradesman to reveal the place and hour of breakfast , for a bribe .
Parsing [sent. 8901 len. 13]: Expectation and excitement extend further yet , and take a wider range .
Parsing [sent. 8902 len. 30]: From Balls Pond , Mr Perch brings Mrs Perch to spend the day with Mr Dombey 's servants , and accompany them , surreptitiously , to see the wedding .
Parsing [sent. 8903 len. 123]: In Mr Toots 's lodgings , Mr Toots attires himself as if he were at least the Bridegroom ; determined to behold the spectacle in splendour from a secret corner of the gallery , and thither to convey the Chicken : for it is Mr Toots 's desperate intent to point out Florence to the Chicken , then and there , and openly to say , ` Now , Chicken , I will not deceive you any longer ; the friend I have sometimes mentioned to you is myself ; Miss Dombey is the object of my passion ; what are your opinions , Chicken , in this state of things , and what , on the spot , do you advise ?
Parsing [sent. 8904 len. 32]: The so-much-to-be-astonished Chicken , in the meanwhile , dips his beak into a tankard of strong beer , in Mr Toots 's kitchen , and pecks up two pounds of beefsteaks .
Parsing [sent. 8905 len. 51]: In Princess 's Place , Miss Tox is up and doing ; for she too , though in sore distress , is resolved to put a shilling in the hands of Mrs Miff , and see the ceremony which has a cruel fascination for her , from some lonely corner .
Parsing [sent. 8906 len. 137]: The quarters of the wooden Midshipman are all alive ; for Captain Cuttle , in his ankle-jacks and with a huge shirt-collar , is seated at his breakfast , listening to Rob the Grinder as he reads the marriage service to him beforehand , under orders , to the end that the Captain may perfectly understand the solemnity he is about to witness : for which purpose , the Captain gravely lays injunctions on his chaplain , from time to time , to ` put about , ' or to ` overhaul that ` ere article again , ' or to stick to his own duty , and leave the Amens to him , the Captain ; one of which he repeats , whenever a pause is made by Rob the Grinder , with sonorous satisfaction .
Parsing [sent. 8907 len. 44]: Besides all this , and much more , twenty nursery-maids in Mr Dombey 's street alone , have promised twenty families of little women , whose instinctive interest in nuptials dates from their cradles , that they shall go and see the marriage .
Parsing [sent. 8908 len. 32]: Truly , Mr Sownds the Beadle has good reason to feel himself in office , as he suns his portly figure on the church steps , waiting for the marriage hour .
Parsing [sent. 8909 len. 33]: Truly , Mrs Miff has cause to pounce on an unlucky dwarf child , with a giant baby , who peeps in at the porch , and drive her forth with indignation !
Parsing [sent. 8910 len. 14]: Cousin Feenix has come over from abroad , expressly to attend the marriage .
Parsing [sent. 8911 len. 79]: Cousin Feenix was a man about town , forty years ago ; but he is still so juvenile in figure and in manner , and so well got up , that strangers are amazed when they discover latent wrinkles in his lordship 's face , and crows ' feet in his eyes : and first observe him , not exactly certain when he walks across a room , of going quite straight to where he wants to go .
Parsing [sent. 8912 len. 44]: But Cousin Feenix , getting up at half-past seven o'clock or so , is quite another thing from Cousin Feenix got up ; and very dim , indeed , he looks , while being shaved at Long 's Hotel , in Bond Street .
Parsing [sent. 8913 len. 85]: Mr Dombey leaves his dressing-room , amidst a general whisking away of the women on the staircase , who disperse in all directions , with a great rustling of skirts , except Mrs Perch , who , being -LRB- but that she always is -RRB- in an interesting situation , is not nimble , and is obliged to face him , and is ready to sink with confusion as she curtesys ; -- may Heaven avert all evil consequences from the house of Perch !
Parsing [sent. 8914 len. 13]: Mr Dombey walks up to the drawing-room , to bide his time .
Parsing [sent. 8915 len. 32]: Gorgeous are Mr Dombey 's new blue coat , fawn-coloured pantaloons , and lilac waistcoat ; and a whisper goes about the house , that Mr Dombey 's hair is curled .
Parsing [sent. 8916 len. 39]: A double knock announces the arrival of the Major , who is gorgeous too , and wears a whole geranium in his button-hole , and has his hair curled tight and crisp , as well the Native knows .
Parsing [sent. 8917 len. 4]: ` Dombey ! '
Parsing [sent. 8918 len. 15]: says the Major , putting out both hands , ` how are you ? '
Parsing [sent. 8919 len. 14]: ` Major , ' says Mr Dombey , ` how are You ? '
Parsing [sent. 8920 len. 71]: ` By Jove , Sir , ' says the Major , ` Joey B. is in such case this morning , Sir , ' -- and here he hits himself hard upon the breast -- ` In such case this morning , Sir , that , damme , Dombey , he has half a mind to make a double marriage of it , Sir , and take the mother . '
Parsing [sent. 8921 len. 41]: Mr Dombey smiles ; but faintly , even for him ; for Mr Dombey feels that he is going to be related to the mother , and that , under those circumstances , she is not to be joked about .
Parsing [sent. 8922 len. 17]: ` Dombey , ' says the Major , seeing this , ' I give you joy .
Parsing [sent. 8923 len. 6]: I congratulate you , Dombey .
Parsing [sent. 8924 len. 29]: By the Lord , Sir , ' says the Major , ` you are more to be envied , this day , than any man in England ! '
Parsing [sent. 8925 len. 34]: Here again Mr Dombey 's assent is qualified ; because he is going to confer a great distinction on a lady ; and , no doubt , she is to be envied most .
Parsing [sent. 8926 len. 59]: ` As to Edith Granger , Sir , ' pursues the Major , ` there is not a woman in all Europe but might -- and would , Sir , you will allow Bagstock to add -- and would -- give her ears , and her earrings , too , to be in Edith Granger 's place . '
Parsing [sent. 8927 len. 16]: ` You are good enough to say so , Major , ' says Mr Dombey .
Parsing [sent. 8928 len. 13]: ` Dombey , ' returns the Major , ` you know it .
Parsing [sent. 8929 len. 7]: Let us have no false delicacy .
Parsing [sent. 8930 len. 4]: You know it .
Parsing [sent. 8931 len. 13]: Do you know it , or do you not , Dombey ? '
Parsing [sent. 8932 len. 9]: says the Major , almost in a passion .
Parsing [sent. 8933 len. 30]: ` Oh , really , Major -- ' ` Damme , Sir , ' retorts the Major , ` do you know that fact , or do you not ?
Parsing [sent. 8934 len. 2]: Dombey !
Parsing [sent. 8935 len. 6]: Is old Joe your friend ?
Parsing [sent. 8936 len. 52]: Are we on that footing of unreserved intimacy , Dombey , that may justify a man -- a blunt old Joseph B. , Sir -- in speaking out ; or am I to take open order , Dombey , and to keep my distance , and to stand on forms ? '
Parsing [sent. 8937 len. 23]: ` My dear Major Bagstock , ' says Mr Dombey , with a gratified air , ` you are quite warm . '
Parsing [sent. 8938 len. 16]: ` By Gad , Sir , ' says the Major , ' I am warm .
Parsing [sent. 8939 len. 9]: Joseph B. does not deny it , Dombey .
Parsing [sent. 8940 len. 4]: He is warm .
Parsing [sent. 8941 len. 31]: This is an occasion , Sir , that calls forth all the honest sympathies remaining in an old , infernal , battered , used-up , invalided , J. B. carcase .
Parsing [sent. 8942 len. 60]: And I tell you what , Dombey -- at such a time a man must blurt out what he feels , or put a muzzle on ; and Joseph Bagstock tells you to your face , Dombey , as he tells his club behind your back , that he never will be muzzled when Paul Dombey is in question .
Parsing [sent. 8943 len. 24]: Now , damme , Sir , ' concludes the Major , with great firmness , ` what do you make of that ? '
Parsing [sent. 8944 len. 20]: ` Major , ' says Mr Dombey , ' I assure you that I am really obliged to you .
Parsing [sent. 8945 len. 12]: I had no idea of checking your too partial friendship . '
Parsing [sent. 8946 len. 8]: ` Not too partial , Sir ! '
Parsing [sent. 8947 len. 5]: exclaims the choleric Major .
Parsing [sent. 8948 len. 8]: ` Dombey , I deny it . '
Parsing [sent. 8949 len. 18]: ` Your friendship I will say then , ' pursues Mr Dombey , ` on any account .
Parsing [sent. 8950 len. 24]: Nor can I forget , Major , on such an occasion as the present , how much I am indebted to it . '
Parsing [sent. 8951 len. 35]: ` Dombey , ' says the Major , with appropriate action , ` that is the hand of Joseph Bagstock : of plain old Joey B. , Sir , if you like that better !
Parsing [sent. 8952 len. 56]: That is the hand , of which His Royal Highness the late Duke of York , did me the honour to observe , Sir , to His Royal Highness the late Duke of Kent , that it was the hand of Josh : a rough and tough , and possibly an up-to-snuff , old vagabond .
Parsing [sent. 8953 len. 14]: Dombey , may the present moment be the least unhappy of our lives .
Parsing [sent. 8954 len. 5]: God bless you ! '
Parsing [sent. 8955 len. 15]: Now enters Mr Carker , gorgeous likewise , and smiling like a wedding-guest indeed .
Parsing [sent. 8956 len. 50]: He can scarcely let Mr Dombey 's hand go , he is so congratulatory ; and he shakes the Major 's hand so heartily at the same time , that his voice shakes too , in accord with his arms , as it comes sliding from between his teeth .
Parsing [sent. 8957 len. 12]: ` The very day is auspicious , ' says Mr Carker .
Parsing [sent. 8958 len. 8]: ` The brightest and most genial weather !
Parsing [sent. 8959 len. 10]: I hope I am not a moment late ? '
Parsing [sent. 8960 len. 14]: ` Punctual to your time , Sir , ' says the Major . '
Parsing [sent. 8961 len. 14]: I am rejoiced , I am sure , ' says Mr Carker . '
Parsing [sent. 8962 len. 55]: I was afraid I might be a few seconds after the appointed time , for I was delayed by a procession of waggons ; and I took the liberty of riding round to Brook Street ' -- this to Mr Dombey -- ` to leave a few poor rarities of flowers for Mrs Dombey .
Parsing [sent. 8963 len. 70]: A man in my position , and so distinguished as to be invited here , is proud to offer some homage in acknowledgment of his vassalage : and as I have no doubt Mrs Dombey is overwhelmed with what is costly and magnificent ; ' with a strange glance at his patron ; ' I hope the very poverty of my offering , may find favour for it . '
Parsing [sent. 8964 len. 32]: ` Mrs Dombey , that is to be , ' returns Mr Dombey , condescendingly , ` will be very sensible of your attention , Carker , I am sure . '

Parsing [sent. 8966 len. 21]: Forth , in a barouche , ride Mr Dombey , Major Bagstock , and Mr Carker , to the church .
Parsing [sent. 8967 len. 23]: Mr Sownds the Beadle has long risen from the steps , and is in waiting with his cocked hat in his hand .
Parsing [sent. 8968 len. 10]: Mrs Miff curtseys and proposes chairs in the vestry .
Parsing [sent. 8969 len. 8]: Mr Dombey prefers remaining in the church .
Parsing [sent. 8970 len. 32]: As he looks up at the organ , Miss Tox in the gallery shrinks behind the fat leg of a cherubim on a monument , with cheeks like a young Wind .
Parsing [sent. 8971 len. 21]: Captain Cuttle , on the contrary , stands up and waves his hook , in token of welcome and encouragement .
Parsing [sent. 8972 len. 28]: Mr Toots informs the Chicken , behind his hand , that the middle gentleman , he in the fawn-coloured pantaloons , is the father of his love .
Parsing [sent. 8973 len. 39]: The Chicken hoarsely whispers Mr Toots that he 's as stiff a cove as ever he see , but that it is within the resources of Science to double him up , with one blow in the waistcoat .
Parsing [sent. 8974 len. 29]: Mr Sownds and Mrs Miff are eyeing Mr Dombey from a little distance , when the noise of approaching wheels is heard , and Mr Sownds goes out .
Parsing [sent. 8975 len. 44]: Mrs Miff , meeting Mr Dombey 's eye as it is withdrawn from the presumptuous maniac upstairs , who salutes him with so much urbanity , drops a curtsey , and informs him that she believes his ` good lady ' is come .
Parsing [sent. 8976 len. 23]: Then there is a crowding and a whispering at the door , and the good lady enters , with a haughty step .
Parsing [sent. 8977 len. 47]: There is no sign upon her face , of last night 's suffering ; there is no trace in her manner , of the woman on the bended knees , reposing her wild head , in beautiful abandonment , upon the pillow of the sleeping girl .
Parsing [sent. 8978 len. 59]: That girl , all gentle and lovely , is at her side -- a striking contrast to her own disdainful and defiant figure , standing there , composed , erect , inscrutable of will , resplendent and majestic in the zenith of its charms , yet beating down , and treading on , the admiration that it challenges .
Parsing [sent. 8979 len. 19]: There is a pause while Mr Sownds the Beadle glides into the vestry for the clergyman and clerk .
Parsing [sent. 8980 len. 31]: At this juncture , Mrs Skewton speaks to Mr Dombey : more distinctly and emphatically than her custom is , and moving at the same time , close to Edith .
Parsing [sent. 8981 len. 34]: ` My dear Dombey , ' said the good Mama , ' I fear I must relinquish darling Florence after all , and suffer her to go home , as she herself proposed .
Parsing [sent. 8982 len. 24]: After my loss of to-day , my dear Dombey , I feel I shall not have spirits , even for her society . '
Parsing [sent. 8983 len. 10]: ` Had she not better stay with you ? '
Parsing [sent. 8984 len. 5]: returns the Bridegroom . '
Parsing [sent. 8985 len. 8]: I think not , my dear Dombey .
Parsing [sent. 8986 len. 6]: No , I think not .
Parsing [sent. 8987 len. 6]: I shall be better alone .
Parsing [sent. 8988 len. 28]: Besides , my dearest Edith will be her natural and constant guardian when you return , and I had better not encroach upon her trust , perhaps .
Parsing [sent. 8989 len. 5]: She might be jealous .
Parsing [sent. 8990 len. 6]: Eh , dear Edith ? '
Parsing [sent. 8991 len. 20]: The affectionate Mama presses her daughter 's arm , as she says this ; perhaps entreating her attention earnestly .
Parsing [sent. 8992 len. 29]: ` To be serious , my dear Dombey , ' she resumes , ' I will relinquish our dear child , and not inflict my gloom upon her .
Parsing [sent. 8993 len. 8]: We have settled that , just now .
Parsing [sent. 8994 len. 7]: She fully understands , dear Dombey .
Parsing [sent. 8995 len. 11]: Edith , my dear , -- she fully understands . '
Parsing [sent. 8996 len. 11]: Again , the good mother presses her daughter 's arm .
Parsing [sent. 8997 len. 36]: Mr Dombey offers no additional remonstrance ; for the clergyman and clerk appear ; and Mrs Miff , and Mr Sownds the Beadle , group the party in their proper places at the altar rails .
Parsing [sent. 8998 len. 15]: The sun is shining down , upon the golden letters of the ten commandments .
Parsing [sent. 8999 len. 13]: Why does the Bride 's eye read them , one by one ?
Parsing [sent. 9000 len. 17]: Which one of all the ten appears the plainest to her in the glare of light ?
Parsing [sent. 9001 len. 37]: False Gods ; murder ; theft ; the honour that she owes her mother ; -- which is it that appears to leave the wall , and printing itself in glowing letters , on her book !
Parsing [sent. 9002 len. 14]: `` Who giveth this woman to be married to this man ? '' '
Parsing [sent. 9003 len. 5]: Cousin Feenix does that .
Parsing [sent. 9004 len. 10]: He has come from Baden -- Baden on purpose .
Parsing [sent. 9005 len. 43]: ` Confound it , ' Cousin Feenix says -- good-natured creature , Cousin Feenix -- ` when we do get a rich City fellow into the family , let us show him some attention ; let us do something for him . '
Parsing [sent. 9006 len. 17]: I give this woman to be married to this man , ' saith Cousin Feenix therefore .
Parsing [sent. 9007 len. 100]: Cousin Feenix , meaning to go in a straight line , but turning off sideways by reason of his wilful legs , gives the wrong woman to be married to this man , at first -- to wit , a brides-maid of some condition , distantly connected with the family , and ten years Mrs Skewton 's junior -- but Mrs Miff , interposing her mortified bonnet , dexterously turns him back , and runs him , as on castors , full at the ` good lady : ' whom Cousin Feenix giveth to married to this man accordingly .
Parsing [sent. 9008 len. 10]: And will they in the sight of heaven -- ?
Parsing [sent. 9009 len. 12]: Ay , that they will : Mr Dombey says he will .
Parsing [sent. 9010 len. 5]: And what says Edith ?
Parsing [sent. 9011 len. 3]: She will .
Parsing [sent. 9012 len. 47]: So , from that day forward , for better for worse , for richer for poorer , in sickness and in health , to love and to cherish , till death do them part , they plight their troth to one another , and are married .
Parsing [sent. 9013 len. 23]: In a firm , free hand , the Bride subscribes her name in the register , when they adjourn to the vestry .
Parsing [sent. 9014 len. 50]: ` There ai n't a many ladies come here , ' Mrs Miff says with a curtsey -- to look at Mrs Miff , at such a season , is to make her mortified bonnet go down with a dip -- writes their names like this good lady ! '
Parsing [sent. 9015 len. 27]: Mr Sownds the Beadle thinks it is a truly spanking signature , and worthy of the writer -- this , however , between himself and conscience .
Parsing [sent. 9016 len. 12]: Florence signs too , but unapplauded , for her hand shakes .
Parsing [sent. 9017 len. 29]: All the party sign ; Cousin Feenix last ; who puts his noble name into a wrong place , and enrols himself as having been born that morning .
Parsing [sent. 9018 len. 42]: The Major now salutes the Bride right gallantly , and carries out that branch of military tactics in reference to all the ladies : notwithstanding Mrs Skewton 's being extremely hard to kiss , and squeaking shrilly in the sacred edIfice .
Parsing [sent. 9019 len. 7]: The example is followed by Cousin .
Parsing [sent. 9020 len. 7]: Feenix and even by Mr Dombey .
Parsing [sent. 9021 len. 34]: Lastly , Mr Carker , with hIs white teeth glistening , approaches Edith , more as if he meant to bite her , than to taste the sweets that linger on her lips .
Parsing [sent. 9022 len. 45]: There is a glow upon her proud cheek , and a flashing in her eyes , that may be meant to stay him ; but it does not , for he salutes her as the rest have done , and wishes her all happiness .
Parsing [sent. 9023 len. 25]: ` If wishes , ' says he in a low voice , ` are not superfluous , applied to such a union . ' '
Parsing [sent. 9024 len. 20]: I thank you , Sir , ' she answers , with a curled lip , and a heaving bosom .
Parsing [sent. 9025 len. 52]: But , does Edith feel still , as on the night when she knew that Mr Dombey would return to offer his alliance , that Carker knows her thoroughly , and reads her right , and that she is more degraded by his knowledge of her , than by aught else ?
Parsing [sent. 9026 len. 39]: Is it for this reason that her haughtiness shrinks beneath his smile , like snow within the hands that grasps it firmly , and that her imperious glance droops In meeting his , and seeks the ground ? '
Parsing [sent. 9027 len. 67]: I am proud to see , ' said Mr Carker , with a servile stooping of his neck , which the revelations making by his eyes and teeth proclaim to be a lie , ' I am proud to see that my humble offering is graced by Mrs Dombey 's hand , and permitted to hold so favoured a place in so joyful an occasion . '
Parsing [sent. 9028 len. 41]: Though she bends her head , in answer , there is something in the momentary action of her hand , as if she would crush the flowers it holds , and fling them , with contempt , upon the ground .
Parsing [sent. 9029 len. 36]: But , she puts the hand through the arm of her new husband , who has been standing near , conversing with the Major , and is proud again , and motionless , and silent .
Parsing [sent. 9030 len. 10]: The carriages are once more at the church door .
Parsing [sent. 9031 len. 60]: Mr Dombey , with his bride upon his arm , conducts her through the twenty families of little women who are on the steps , and every one of whom remembers the fashion and the colour of her every article of dress from that moment , and reproduces it on her doll , who is for ever being married .
Parsing [sent. 9032 len. 9]: Cleopatra and Cousin Feenix enter the same carriage .
Parsing [sent. 9033 len. 36]: The Major hands into a second carriage , Florence , and the bridesmaid who so narrowly escaped being given away by mistake , and then enters it himself , and is followed by Mr Carker .
Parsing [sent. 9034 len. 19]: Horses prance and caper ; coachmen and footmen shine in fluttering favours , flowers , and new-made liveries .
Parsing [sent. 9035 len. 54]: Away they dash and rattle through the streets ; and as they pass along , a thousand heads are turned to look at them , and a thousand sober moralists revenge themselves for not being married too , that morning , by reflecting that these people little think such happiness ca n't last .
Parsing [sent. 9036 len. 23]: Miss Tox emerges from behind the cherubim 's leg , when all is quiet , and comes slowly down from the gallery .
Parsing [sent. 9037 len. 13]: Miss Tox 's eyes are red , and her pocket-handkerchief is damp .
Parsing [sent. 9038 len. 16]: She is wounded , but not exasperated , and she hopes they may be happy .
Parsing [sent. 9039 len. 62]: She quite admits to herself the beauty of the bride , and her own comparatively feeble and faded attractions ; but the stately image of Mr Dombey in his lilac waistcoat , and his fawn-coloured pantaloons , is present to her mind , and Miss Tox weeps afresh , behind her veil , on her way home to Princess 's Place .
Parsing [sent. 9040 len. 55]: Captain Cuttle , having joined in all the amens and responses , with a devout growl , feels much improved by his religious exercises ; and in a peaceful frame of mind pervades the body of the church , glazed hat in hand , and reads the tablet to the memory of little Paul .
Parsing [sent. 9041 len. 19]: The gallant Mr Toots , attended by the faithful Chicken , leaves the building in torments of love .
Parsing [sent. 9042 len. 42]: The Chicken is as yet unable to elaborate a scheme for winning Florence , but his first idea has gained possession of him , and he thinks the doubling up of Mr Dombey would be a move in the right direction .
Parsing [sent. 9043 len. 93]: Mr Dombey 's servants come out of their hiding-places , and prepare to rush to Brook Street , when they are delayed by symptoms of indisposition on the part of Mrs Perch , who entreats a glass of water , and becomes alarming ; Mrs Perch gets better soon , however , and is borne away ; and Mrs Miff , and Mr Sownds the Beadle , sit upon the steps to count what they have gained by the affair , and talk it over , while the sexton tolls a funeral .
Parsing [sent. 9044 len. 41]: Now , the carriages arrive at the Bride 's residence , and the players on the bells begin to jingle , and the band strikes up , and Mr Punch , that model of connubial bliss , salutes his wife .
Parsing [sent. 9045 len. 35]: Now , the people run , and push , and press round in a gaping throng , while Mr Dombey , leading Mrs Dombey by the hand , advances solemnly into the Feenix Halls .
Parsing [sent. 9046 len. 15]: Now , the rest of the wedding party alight , and enter after them .
Parsing [sent. 9047 len. 29]: And why does Mr Carker , passing through the people to the hall-door , think of the old woman who called to him in the Grove that morning ?
Parsing [sent. 9048 len. 33]: Or why does Florence , as she passes , think , with a tremble , of her childhood , when she was lost , and of the visage of Good Mrs Brown ?
Parsing [sent. 9049 len. 60]: Now , there are more congratulations on this happiest of days , and more company , though not much ; and now they leave the drawing-room , and range themselves at table in the dark-brown dining-room , which no confectioner can brighten up , let him garnish the exhausted negroes with as many flowers and love-knots as he will .
Parsing [sent. 9050 len. 20]: The pastry-cook has done his duty like a man , though , and a rich breakfast is set forth .
Parsing [sent. 9051 len. 12]: Mr and Mrs Chick have joined the party , among others .
Parsing [sent. 9052 len. 43]: Mrs Chick admires that Edith should be , by nature , such a perfect Dombey ; and is affable and confidential to Mrs Skewton , whose mind is relieved of a great load , and who takes her share of the champagne .
Parsing [sent. 9053 len. 53]: The very tall young man who suffered from excitement early , is better ; but a vague sentiment of repentance has seized upon him , and he hates the other very tall young man , and wrests dishes from him by violence , and takes a grim delight in disobliging the company .
Parsing [sent. 9054 len. 27]: The company are cool and calm , and do not outrage the black hatchments of pictures looking down upon them , by any excess of mirth .
Parsing [sent. 9055 len. 21]: Cousin Feenix and the Major are the gayest there ; but Mr Carker has a smile for the whole table .
Parsing [sent. 9056 len. 17]: He has an especial smile for the Bride , who very , very seldom meets it .
Parsing [sent. 9057 len. 48]: Cousin Feenix rises , when the company have breakfasted , and the servants have left the room ; and wonderfully young he looks , with his white wristbands almost covering his hands -LRB- otherwise rather bony -RRB- , and the bloom of the champagne in his cheeks .
Parsing [sent. 9058 len. 47]: ` Upon my honour , ' says Cousin Feenix , ` although it 's an unusual sort of thing in a private gentleman 's house , I must beg leave to call upon you to drink what is usually called a -- in fact a toast .
Parsing [sent. 9059 len. 8]: The Major very hoarsely indicates his approval .
Parsing [sent. 9060 len. 25]: Mr Carker , bending his head forward over the table in the direction of Cousin Feenix , smiles and nods a great many times .
Parsing [sent. 9061 len. 24]: ` A -- in fact it 's not a -- ' Cousin Feenix beginning again , thus , comes to a dead stop .
Parsing [sent. 9062 len. 6]: ` Hear , hear ! '
Parsing [sent. 9063 len. 10]: says the Major , in a tone of conviction .
Parsing [sent. 9064 len. 187]: Mr Carker softly claps his hands , and bending forward over the table again , smiles and nods a great many more times than before , as if he were particularly struck by this last observation , and desired personally to express his sense of the good it has done ` It is , ' says Cousin Feenix , ` an occasion in fact , when the general usages of life may be a little departed from , without impropriety ; and although I never was an orator in my life , and when I was in the House of Commons , and had the honour of seconding the address , was -- in fact , was laid up for a fortnight with the consciousness of failure -- ' The Major and Mr Carker are so much delighted by this fragment of personal history , that Cousin Feenix laughs , and addressing them individually , goes on to say : ` And in point of fact , when I was devilish ill -- still , you know , I feel that a duty devolves upon me .
Parsing [sent. 9065 len. 29]: And when a duty devolves upon an Englishman , he is bound to get out of it , in my opinion , in the best way he can .
Parsing [sent. 9066 len. 2]: Well !
Parsing [sent. 9067 len. 42]: our family has had the gratification , to-day , of connecting itself , in the person of my lovely and accomplished relative , whom I now see -- in point of fact , present -- ' Here there is general applause .
Parsing [sent. 9068 len. 64]: ` Present , ' repeats Cousin Feenix , feeling that it is a neat point which will bear repetition , -- ` with one who -- that is to say , with a man , at whom the finger of scorn can never -- in fact , with my honourable friend Dombey , if he will allow me to call him so . '
Parsing [sent. 9069 len. 36]: Cousin Feenix bows to Mr Dombey ; Mr Dombey solemnly returns the bow ; everybody is more or less gratified and affected by this extraordinary , and perhaps unprecedented , appeal to the feelings . '
Parsing [sent. 9070 len. 141]: I have not , ' says Cousin Feenix , ` enjoyed those opportunities which I could have desired , of cultivating the acquaintance of my friend Dombey , and studying those qualities which do equal honour to his head , and , in point of fact , to his heart ; for it has been my misfortune to be , as we used to say in my time in the House of Commons , when it was not the custom to allude to the Lords , and when the order of parliamentary proceedings was perhaps better observed than it is now -- to be in -- in point of fact , ' says Cousin Feenix , cherishing his joke , with great slyness , and finally bringing it out with a jerk , '' ` in another place ! '' '
Parsing [sent. 9071 len. 12]: The Major falls into convulsions , and is recovered with difficulty .
Parsing [sent. 9072 len. 64]: ` But I know sufficient of my friend Dombey , ' resumes Cousin Feenix in a graver tone , as if he had suddenly become a sadder and wiser man ' ` to know that he is , in point of fact , what may be emphatically called a -- a merchant -- a British merchant -- and a -- and a man .
Parsing [sent. 9073 len. 96]: And although I have been resident abroad , for some years -LRB- it would give me great pleasure to receive my friend Dombey , and everybody here , at Baden -- Baden , and to have an opportunity of making 'em known to the Grand Duke -RRB- , still I know enough , I flatter myself , of my lovely and accomplished relative , to know that she possesses every requisite to make a man happy , and that her marriage with my friend Dombey is one of inclination and affection on both sides . '
Parsing [sent. 9074 len. 8]: Many smiles and nods from Mr Carker .
Parsing [sent. 9075 len. 28]: ` Therefore , ' says Cousin Feenix , ' I congratulate the family of which I am a member , on the acquisition of my friend Dombey .
Parsing [sent. 9076 len. 59]: I congratulate my friend Dombey on his union with my lovely and accomplished relative who possesses every requisite to make a man happy ; and I take the liberty of calling on you all , in point of fact , to congratulate both my friend Dombey and my lovely and accomplished relative , on the present occasion . '
Parsing [sent. 9077 len. 24]: The speech of Cousin Feenix is received with great applause , and Mr Dombey returns thanks on behalf of himself and Mrs Dombey .
Parsing [sent. 9078 len. 8]: J. B. shortly afterwards proposes Mrs Skewton .
Parsing [sent. 9079 len. 23]: The breakfast languishes when that is done , the violated hatchments are avenged , and Edith rises to assume her travelling dress .
Parsing [sent. 9080 len. 12]: All the servants in the meantime , have been breakfasting below .
Parsing [sent. 9081 len. 26]: Champagne has grown too common among them to be mentioned , and roast fowls , raised pies , and lobster-salad , have become mere drugs .
Parsing [sent. 9082 len. 17]: The very tall young man has recovered his spirits , and again alludes to the exciseman .
Parsing [sent. 9083 len. 23]: His comrade 's eye begins to emulate his own , and he , too , stares at objects without taking cognizance thereof .
Parsing [sent. 9084 len. 68]: There is a general redness in the faces of the ladies ; in the face of Mrs Perch particularly , who is joyous and beaming , and lifted so far above the cares of life , that if she were asked just now to direct a wayfarer to Ball 's Pond , where her own cares lodge , she would have some difficulty in recalling the way .
Parsing [sent. 9085 len. 48]: Mr Towlinson has proposed the happy pair ; to which the silver-headed butler has responded neatly , and with emotion ; for he half begins to think he is an old retainer of the family , and that he is bound to be affected by these changes .
Parsing [sent. 9086 len. 13]: The whole party , and especially the ladies , are very frolicsome .
Parsing [sent. 9087 len. 38]: Mr Dombey 's cook , who generally takes the lead in society , has said , it is impossible to settle down after this , and why not go , in a party , to the play ?
Parsing [sent. 9088 len. 39]: Everybody -LRB- Mrs Perch included -RRB- has agreed to this ; even the Native , who is tigerish in his drink , and who alarms the ladies -LRB- Mrs Perch particularly -RRB- by the rolling of his eyes .
Parsing [sent. 9089 len. 35]: One of the very tall young men has even proposed a ball after the play , and it presents itself to no one -LRB- Mrs Perch included -RRB- in the light of an impossibility .
Parsing [sent. 9090 len. 73]: Words have arisen between the housemaid and Mr Towlinson ; she , on the authority of an old saw , asserting marriages to be made in Heaven : he , affecting to trace the manufacture elsewhere ; he , supposing that she says so , because she thinks of being married her own self : she , saying , Lord forbid , at any rate , that she should ever marry him .
Parsing [sent. 9091 len. 56]: To calm these flying taunts , the silver-headed butler rises to propose the health of Mr Towlinson , whom to know is to esteem , and to esteem is to wish well settled in life with the object of his choice , wherever -LRB- here the silver-headed butler eyes the housemaid -RRB- she may be .
Parsing [sent. 9092 len. 66]: Mr Towlinson returns thanks in a speech replete with feeling , of which the peroration turns on foreigners , regarding whom he says they may find favour , sometimes , with weak and inconstant intellects that can be led away by hair , but all he hopes , is , he may never hear of no foreigner never boning nothing out of no travelling chariot .
Parsing [sent. 9093 len. 45]: The eye of Mr Towlinson is so severe and so expressive here , that the housemaid is turning hysterical , when she and all the rest , roused by the intelligence that the Bride is going away , hurry upstairs to witness her departure .
Parsing [sent. 9094 len. 22]: The chariot is at the door ; the Bride is descending to the hall , where Mr Dombey waits for her .
Parsing [sent. 9095 len. 33]: Florence is ready on the staircase to depart too ; and Miss Nipper , who has held a middle state between the parlour and the kitchen , is prepared to accompany her .
Parsing [sent. 9096 len. 14]: As Edith appears , Florence hastens towards her , to bid her farewell .
Parsing [sent. 9097 len. 9]: Is Edith cold , that she should tremble !
Parsing [sent. 9098 len. 28]: Is there anything unnatural or unwholesome in the touch of Florence , that the beautiful form recedes and contracts , as if it could not bear it !
Parsing [sent. 9099 len. 27]: Is there so much hurry in this going away , that Edith , with a wave of her hand , sweeps on , and is gone !
Parsing [sent. 9100 len. 35]: Mrs Skewton , overpowered by her feelings as a mother , sinks on her sofa in the Cleopatra attitude , when the clatter of the chariot wheels is lost , and sheds several tears .
Parsing [sent. 9101 len. 36]: The Major , coming with the rest of the company from table , endeavours to comfort her ; but she will not be comforted on any terms , and so the Major takes his leave .
Parsing [sent. 9102 len. 13]: Cousin Feenix takes his leave , and Mr Carker takes his leave .
Parsing [sent. 9103 len. 6]: The guests all go away .
Parsing [sent. 9104 len. 18]: Cleopatra , left alone , feels a little giddy from her strong emotion , and falls asleep .
Parsing [sent. 9105 len. 6]: Giddiness prevails below stairs too .
Parsing [sent. 9106 len. 34]: The very tall young man whose excitement came on so soon , appears to have his head glued to the table in the pantry , and can not be detached from -- it .
Parsing [sent. 9107 len. 52]: A violent revulsion has taken place in the spirits of Mrs Perch , who is low on account of Mr Perch , and tells cook that she fears he is not so much attached to his home , as he used to be , when they were only nine in family .
Parsing [sent. 9108 len. 20]: Mr Towlinson has a singing in his ears and a large wheel going round and round inside his head .
Parsing [sent. 9109 len. 14]: The housemaid wishes it was n't wicked to wish that one was dead .
Parsing [sent. 9110 len. 45]: There is a general delusion likewise , in these lower regions , on the subject of time ; everybody conceiving that it ought to be , at the earliest , ten o'clock at night , whereas it is not yet three in the afternoon .
Parsing [sent. 9111 len. 34]: A shadowy idea of wickedness committed , haunts every individual in the party ; and each one secretly thinks the other a companion in guilt , whom it would be agreeable to avoid .
Parsing [sent. 9112 len. 17]: No man or woman has the hardihood to hint at the projected visit to the play .
Parsing [sent. 9113 len. 16]: Anyone reviving the notion of the ball , would be scouted as a malignant idiot .
Parsing [sent. 9114 len. 19]: Mrs Skewton sleeps upstairs , two hours afterwards , and naps are not yet over in the kitchen .
Parsing [sent. 9115 len. 45]: The hatchments in the dining-room look down on crumbs , dirty plates , spillings of wine , half-thawed ice , stale discoloured heel-taps , scraps of lobster , drumsticks of fowls , and pensive jellies , gradually resolving themselves into a lukewarm gummy soup .
Parsing [sent. 9116 len. 20]: The marriage is , by this time , almost as denuded of its show and garnish as the breakfast .
Parsing [sent. 9117 len. 105]: Mr Dombey 's servants moralise so much about it , and are so repentant over their early tea , at home , that by eight o'clock or so , they settle down into confirmed seriousness ; and Mr Perch , arriving at that time from the City , fresh and jocular , with a white waistcoat and a comic song , ready to spend the evening , and prepared for any amount of dissipation , is amazed to find himself coldly received , and Mrs Perch but poorly , and to have the pleasing duty of escorting that lady home by the next omnibus .
Parsing [sent. 9118 len. 4]: Night closes in .
Parsing [sent. 9119 len. 67]: Florence , having rambled through the handsome house , from room to room , seeks her own chamber , where the care of Edith has surrounded her with luxuries and comforts ; and divesting herself of her handsome dress , puts on her old simple mourning for dear Paul , and sits down to read , with Diogenes winking and blinking on the ground beside her .
Parsing [sent. 9120 len. 7]: But Florence can not read tonight .
Parsing [sent. 9121 len. 15]: The house seems strange and new , and there are loud echoes in it .
Parsing [sent. 9122 len. 20]: There is a shadow on her heart : she knows not why or what : but it is heavy .
Parsing [sent. 9123 len. 32]: Florence shuts her book , and gruff Diogenes , who takes that for a signal , puts his paws upon her lap , and rubs his ears against her caressing hands .
Parsing [sent. 9124 len. 37]: But Florence can not see him plainly , in a little time , for there is a mist between her eyes and him , and her dead brother and dead mother shine in it like angels .
Parsing [sent. 9125 len. 15]: Walter , too , poor wandering shipwrecked boy , oh , where is he ?
Parsing [sent. 9126 len. 16]: The Major do n't know ; that 's for certain ; and do n't care .
Parsing [sent. 9127 len. 97]: The Major , having choked and slumbered , all the afternoon , has taken a late dinner at his club , and now sits over his pint of wine , driving a modest young man , with a fresh-coloured face , at the next table -LRB- who would give a handsome sum to be able to rise and go away , but can not do it -RRB- to the verge of madness , by anecdotes of Bagstock , Sir , at Dombey 's wedding , and Old Joe 's devilish gentle manly friend , Lord Feenix .
Parsing [sent. 9128 len. 40]: While Cousin Feenix , who ought to be at Long 's , and in bed , finds himself , instead , at a gaming-table , where his wilful legs have taken him , perhaps , in his own despite .
Parsing [sent. 9129 len. 23]: Night , like a giant , fills the church , from pavement to roof , and holds dominion through the silent hours .
Parsing [sent. 9130 len. 38]: Pale dawn again comes peeping through the windows : and , giving place to day , sees night withdraw into the vaults , and follows it , and drives it out , and hides among the dead .
Parsing [sent. 9131 len. 37]: The timid mice again cower close together , when the great door clashes , and Mr Sownds and Mrs Miff treading the circle of their daily lives , unbroken as a marriage ring , come in .
Parsing [sent. 9132 len. 79]: Again , the cocked hat and the mortified bonnet stand in the background at the marriage hour ; and again this man taketh this woman , and this woman taketh this man , on the solemn terms : ` To have and to hold , from this day forward , for better for worse , for richer for poorer , in sickness and in health , to love and to cherish , until death do them part . '
Parsing [sent. 9133 len. 26]: The very words that Mr Carker rides into town repeating , with his mouth stretched to the utmost , as he picks his dainty way .
Parsing [sent. 9134 len. 3]: CHAPTER 32 .
Parsing [sent. 9135 len. 41]: The Wooden Midshipman goes to Pieces Honest Captain Cuttle , as the weeks flew over him in his fortified retreat , by no means abated any of his prudent provisions against surprise , because of the non-appearance of the enemy .
Parsing [sent. 9136 len. 70]: The Captain argued that his present security was too profound and wonderful to endure much longer ; he knew that when the wind stood in a fair quarter , the weathercock was seldom nailed there ; and he was too well acquainted with the determined and dauntless character of Mrs MacStinger , to doubt that that heroic woman had devoted herself to the task of his discovery and capture .
Parsing [sent. 9137 len. 65]: Trembling beneath the weight of these reasons , Captain Cuttle lived a very close and retired life ; seldom stirring abroad until after dark ; venturing even then only into the obscurest streets ; never going forth at all on Sundays ; and both within and without the walls of his retreat , avoiding bonnets , as if they were worn by raging lions .
Parsing [sent. 9138 len. 29]: The Captain never dreamed that in the event of his being pounced upon by Mrs MacStinger , in his walks , it would be possible to offer resistance .
Parsing [sent. 9139 len. 9]: He felt that it could not be done .
Parsing [sent. 9140 len. 24]: He saw himself , in his mind 's eye , put meekly in a hackney-coach , and carried off to his old lodgings .
Parsing [sent. 9141 len. 64]: He foresaw that , once immured there , he was a lost man : his hat gone ; Mrs MacStinger watchful of him day and night ; reproaches heaped upon his head , before the infant family ; himself the guilty object of suspicion and distrust ; an ogre in the children 's eyes , and in their mother 's a detected traitor .
Parsing [sent. 9142 len. 25]: A violent perspiration , and a lowness of spirits , always came over the Captain as this gloomy picture presented itself to his imagination .
Parsing [sent. 9143 len. 18]: It generally did so previous to his stealing out of doors at night for air and exercise .
Parsing [sent. 9144 len. 68]: Sensible of the risk he ran , the Captain took leave of Rob , at those times , with the solemnity which became a man who might never return : exhorting him , in the event of his -LRB- the Captain 's -RRB- being lost sight of , for a time , to tread in the paths of virtue , and keep the brazen instruments well polished .
Parsing [sent. 9145 len. 67]: But not to throw away a chance ; and to secure to himself a means , in case of the worst , of holding communication with the external world ; Captain Cuttle soon conceived the happy idea of teaching Rob the Grinder some secret signal , by which that adherent might make his presence and fidelity known to his commander , in the hour of adversity .
Parsing [sent. 9146 len. 25]: After much cogitation , the Captain decided in favour of instructing him to whistle the marine melody , ` Oh cheerily , cheerily ! '

Parsing [sent. 9164 len. 71]: Rob the Grinder discharged himself of his duty with so much exactness and judgment , when thus put to the proof , that the Captain presented him , at divers times , with seven sixpences , in token of satisfaction ; and gradually felt stealing over his spirit the resignation of a man who had made provision for the worst , and taken every reasonable precaution against an unrelenting fate .
Parsing [sent. 9165 len. 18]: Nevertheless , the Captain did not tempt ill-fortune , by being a whit more venturesome than before .
Parsing [sent. 9166 len. 111]: Though he considered it a point of good breeding in himself , as a general friend of the family , to attend Mr Dombey 's wedding -LRB- of which he had heard from Mr Perch -RRB- , and to show that gentleman a pleasant and approving countenance from the gallery , he had repaired to the church in a hackney cabriolet with both windows up ; and might have scrupled even to make that venture , in his dread of Mrs MacStinger , but that the lady 's attendance on the ministry of the Reverend Melchisedech rendered it peculiarly unlikely that she would be found in communion with the Establishment .
Parsing [sent. 9167 len. 41]: The Captain got safe home again , and fell into the ordinary routine of his new life , without encountering any more direct alarm from the enemy , than was suggested to him by the daily bonnets in the street .
Parsing [sent. 9168 len. 13]: But other subjects began to lay heavy on the Captain 's mind .

Parsing [sent. 9171 len. 23]: Florence did not even know of the old man 's disappearance , and Captain Cuttle had not the heart to tell her .
Parsing [sent. 9172 len. 60]: Indeed the Captain , as his own hopes of the generous , handsome , gallant-hearted youth , whom he had loved , according to his rough manner , from a child , began to fade , and faded more and more from day to day , shrunk with instinctive pain from the thought of exchanging a word with Florence .

Parsing [sent. 9174 len. 50]: With a dark horizon gathering around their common hopes , however , that darkened every hour , the Captain almost felt as if he were a new misfortune and affliction to her ; and was scarcely less afraid of a visit from Florence , than from Mrs MacStinger herself .
Parsing [sent. 9175 len. 35]: It was a chill dark autumn evening , and Captain Cuttle had ordered a fire to be kindled in the little back parlour , now more than ever like the cabin of a ship .
Parsing [sent. 9176 len. 52]: The rain fell fast , and the wind blew hard ; and straying out on the house-top by that stormy bedroom of his old friend , to take an observation of the weather , the Captain 's heart died within him , when he saw how wild and desolate it was .
Parsing [sent. 9177 len. 81]: Not that he associated the weather of that time with poor Walter 's destiny , or doubted that if Providence had doomed him to be lost and shipwrecked , it was over , long ago ; but that beneath an outward influence , quite distinct from the subject-matter of his thoughts , the Captain 's spirits sank , and his hopes turned pale , as those of wiser men had often done before him , and will often do again .
Parsing [sent. 9178 len. 39]: Captain Cuttle , addressing his face to the sharp wind and slanting rain , looked up at the heavy scud that was flying fast over the wilderness of house-tops , and looked for something cheery there in vain .

Parsing [sent. 9463 len. 3]: CHAPTER 33 .
Parsing [sent. 9464 len. 33]: Contrasts Turn we our eyes upon two homes ; not lying side by side , but wide apart , though both within easy range and reach of the great city of London .
Parsing [sent. 9465 len. 13]: The first is situated in the green and wooded country near Norwood .
Parsing [sent. 9466 len. 25]: It is not a mansion ; it is of no pretensions as to size ; but it is beautifully arranged , and tastefully kept .
Parsing [sent. 9467 len. 80]: The lawn , the soft , smooth slope , the flower-garden , the clumps of trees where graceful forms of ash and willow are not wanting , the conservatory , the rustic verandah with sweet-smelling creeping plants entwined about the pillars , the simple exterior of the house , the well-ordered offices , though all upon the diminutive scale proper to a mere cottage , bespeak an amount of elegant comfort within , that might serve for a palace .
Parsing [sent. 9468 len. 20]: This indication is not without warrant ; for , within , it is a house of refinement and luxury .
Parsing [sent. 9469 len. 59]: Rich colours , excellently blended , meet the eye at every turn ; in the furniture -- its proportions admirably devised to suit the shapes and sizes of the small rooms ; on the walls ; upon the floors ; tingeing and subduing the light that comes in through the odd glass doors and windows here and there .
Parsing [sent. 9470 len. 47]: There are a few choice prints and pictures too ; in quaint nooks and recesses there is no want of books ; and there are games of skill and chance set forth on tables -- fantastic chessmen , dice , backgammon , cards , and billiards .
Parsing [sent. 9471 len. 20]: And yet amidst this opulence of comfort , there is something in the general air that is not well .
Parsing [sent. 9472 len. 29]: Is it that the carpets and the cushions are too soft and noiseless , so that those who move or repose among them seem to act by stealth ?
Parsing [sent. 9473 len. 47]: Is it that the prints and pictures do not commemorate great thoughts or deeds , or render nature in the Poetry of landscape , hall , or hut , but are of one voluptuous cast -- mere shows of form and colour -- and no more ?
Parsing [sent. 9474 len. 30]: Is it that the books have all their gold outside , and that the titles of the greater part qualify them to be companions of the prints and pictures ?
Parsing [sent. 9475 len. 57]: Is it that the completeness and the beauty of the place are here and there belied by an affectation of humility , in some unimportant and inexpensive regard , which is as false as the face of the too truly painted portrait hanging yonder , or its original at breakfast in his easy chair below it ?
Parsing [sent. 9476 len. 39]: Or is it that , with the daily breath of that original and master of all here , there issues forth some subtle portion of himself , which gives a vague expression of himself to everything about him ?
Parsing [sent. 9477 len. 13]: It is Mr Carker the Manager who sits in the easy chair .
Parsing [sent. 9478 len. 59]: A gaudy parrot in a burnished cage upon the table tears at the wires with her beak , and goes walking , upside down , in its dome-top , shaking her house and screeching ; but Mr Carker is indifferent to the bird , and looks with a musing smile at a picture on the opposite wall . Parsing [sent. 9490 len. 37]: The second home is on the other side of London , near to where the busy great north road of bygone days is silent and almost deserted , except by wayfarers who toil along on foot .
Parsing [sent. 9491 len. 41]: It is a poor small house , barely and sparely furnished , but very clean ; and there is even an attempt to decorate it , shown in the homely flowers trained about the porch and in the narrow garden .
Parsing [sent. 9492 len. 24]: The neighbourhood in which it stands has as little of the country to recommend ` it , as it has of the town .
Parsing [sent. 9493 len. 9]: It is neither of the town nor country .
Parsing [sent. 9494 len. 135]: The former , like the giant in his travelling boots , has made a stride and passed it , and has set his brick-and-mortar heel a long way in advance ; but the intermediate space between the giant 's feet , as yet , is only blighted country , and not town ; and , here , among a few tall chimneys belching smoke all day and night , and among the brick-fields and the lanes where turf is cut , and where the fences tumble down , and where the dusty nettles grow , and where a scrap or two of hedge may yet be seen , and where the bird-catcher still comes occasionally , though he swears every time to come no more -- this second home is to be found . '
Parsing [sent. 9495 len. 19]: She who inhabits it , is she who left the first in her devotion to an outcast brother .
Parsing [sent. 9496 len. 59]: She withdrew from that home its redeeming spirit , and from its master 's breast his solitary angel : but though his liking for her is gone , after this ungrateful slight as he considers it ; and though he abandons her altogether in return , an old idea of her is not quite forgotten even by him .
Parsing [sent. 9497 len. 36]: Let her flower-garden , in which he never sets his foot , but which is yet maintained , among all his costly alterations , as if she had quitted it but yesterday , bear witness !
Parsing [sent. 9498 len. 47]: Harriet Carker has changed since then , and on her beauty there has fallen a heavier shade than Time of his unassisted self can cast , all-potent as he is -- the shadow of anxiety and sorrow , and the daily struggle of a poor existence .
Parsing [sent. 9499 len. 43]: But it is beauty still ; and still a gentle , quiet , and retiring beauty that must be sought out , for it can not vaunt itself ; if it could , it would be what it is , no more .
Parsing [sent. 9500 len. 2]: Yes .
Parsing [sent. 9501 len. 134]: This slight , small , patient figure , neatly dressed in homely stuffs , and indicating nothing but the dull , household virtues , that have so little in common with the received idea of heroism and greatness , unless , indeed , any ray of them should shine through the lives of the great ones of the earth , when it becomes a constellation and is tracked in Heaven straightway -- this slight , small , patient figure , leaning on the man still young but worn and grey , is she , his sister , who , of all the world , went over to him in his shame and put her hand in his , and with a sweet composure and determination , led him hopefully upon his barren way .
Parsing [sent. 9502 len. 11]: ` It is early , John , ' she said .
Parsing [sent. 9503 len. 9]: ` Why do you go so early ? '
Parsing [sent. 9504 len. 10]: ` Not many minutes earlier than usual , Harriet .
