Parsing [sent. 16039 len. 122]: The church Walter had chosen for the purpose , was a mouldy old church in a yard , hemmed in by a labyrinth of back streets and courts , with a little burying-ground round it , and itself buried in a kind of vault , formed by the neighbouring houses , and paved with echoing stones It was a great dim , shabby pile , with high old oaken pews , among which about a score of people lost themselves every Sunday ; while the clergyman 's voice drowsily resounded through the emptiness , and the organ rumbled and rolled as if the church had got the colic , for want of a congregation to keep the wind and damp out .
Parsing [sent. 16040 len. 33]: But so far was this city church from languishing for the company of other churches , that spires were clustered round it , as the masts of shipping cluster on the river .
Parsing [sent. 16041 len. 17]: It would have been hard to count them from its steeple-top , they were so many .
Parsing [sent. 16042 len. 13]: In almost every yard and blind-place near , there was a church .
Parsing [sent. 16043 len. 21]: The confusion of bells when Susan and Mr Toots betook themselves towards it on the Sunday morning , was deafening .
Parsing [sent. 16044 len. 14]: There were twenty churches close together , clamouring for people to come in .
Parsing [sent. 16045 len. 76]: The two stray sheep in question were penned by a beadle in a commodious pew , and , being early , sat for some time counting the congregation , listening to the disappointed bell high up in the tower , or looking at a shabby little old man in the porch behind the screen , who was ringing the same , like the Bull in Cock Robin , ' with his foot in a stirrup .
Parsing [sent. 16046 len. 49]: Mr Toots , after a lengthened survey of the large books on the reading-desk , whispered Miss Nipper that he wondered where the banns were kept , but that young lady merely shook her head and frowned ; repelling for the time all approaches of a temporal nature .
Parsing [sent. 16047 len. 30]: Mr Toots , however , appearing unable to keep his thoughts from the banns , was evidently looking out for them during the whole preliminary portion of the service .
Parsing [sent. 16048 len. 37]: As the time for reading them approached , the poor young gentleman manifested great anxiety and trepidation , which was not diminished by the unexpected apparition of the Captain in the front row of the gallery .
Parsing [sent. 16049 len. 130]: When the clerk handed up a list to the clergyman , Mr Toots , being then seated , held on by the seat of the pew ; but when the names of Walter Gay and Florence Dombey were read aloud as being in the third and last stage of that association , he was so entirley conquered by his feelings as to rush from the church without his hat , followed by the beadle and pew-opener , and two gentlemen of the medical profeesion , who happened to be present ; of whom the first-named presently returned for that article , informing Miss Nipper in a whisper that she was not to make herself uneasy about the gentleman , as the gentleman said his indisposition was of no consequence .
Parsing [sent. 16050 len. 81]: Miss Nipper , feeling that the eyes of that integral portion of Europe which lost itself weekly among the high-backed pews , were upon her , would have been sufficient embarrassed by this incident , though it had terminated here ; the more so , as the Captain in the front row of the gallery , was in a state of unmitigated consciousness which could hardly fail to express to the congregation that he had some mysterious connection with it .
Parsing [sent. 16051 len. 17]: But the extreme restlessness of Mr Toots painfully increased and protracted the delicacy of her situation .
Parsing [sent. 16052 len. 96]: That young gentleman , incapable , in his state of mind , of remaining alone in the churchyard , a prey to solitary meditation , and also desirous , no doubt , of testifying his respect for the offices he had in some measure interrupted , suddenly returned -- not coming back to the pew , but stationing himself on a free seat in the aisle , between two elderly females who were in the habit of receiving their portion of a weekly dole of bread then set forth on a shelf in the porch .
Parsing [sent. 16053 len. 36]: In this conjunction Mr Toots remained , greatly disturbing the congregation , who felt it impossible to avoid looking at him , until his feelings overcame him again , when he departed silently and suddenly .
Parsing [sent. 16054 len. 123]: Not venturing to trust himself in the church any more , and yet wishing to have some social participation in what was going on there , Mr Toots was , after this , seen from time to time , looking in , with a lorn aspect , at one or other of the windows ; and as there were several windows accessible to him from without , and as his restlessness was very great , it not only became difficult to conceive at which window he would appear next , but likewise became necessary , as it were , for the whole congregation to speculate upon the chances of the different windows , during the comparative leisure afforded them by the sermon .
Parsing [sent. 16055 len. 105]: Mr Toots 's movements in the churchyard were so eccentric , that he seemed generally to defeat all calculation , and to appear , like the conjuror 's figure , where he was least expected ; and the effect of these mysterious presentations was much increased by its being difficult to him to see in , and easy to everybody else to see out : which occasioned his remaining , every time , longer than might have been expected , with his face close to the glass , until he all at once became aware that all eyes were upon him , and vanished .
Parsing [sent. 16056 len. 101]: These proceedings on the part of Mr Toots , and the strong individual consciousness of them that was exhibited by the Captain , rendered Miss Nipper 's position so responsible a one , that she was mightily relieved by the conclusion of the service ; and was hardly so affable to Mr Toots as usual , when he informed her and the Captain , on the way back , that now he was sure he had no hope , you know , he felt more comfortable -- at least not exactly more comfortable , but more comfortably and completely miserable .
Parsing [sent. 16057 len. 22]: Swiftly now , indeed , the time flew by until it was the evening before the day appointed for the marriage .

Parsing [sent. 16307 len. 51]: The confidence and love of children may be given many times , and will spring up in many places ; but the woman 's heart of Florence , with its undivided treasure , can be yielded only once , and under slight or change , can only droop and die .
Parsing [sent. 16308 len. 22]: They take the streets that are the quietest , and do not go near that in which her old home stands .
Parsing [sent. 16309 len. 28]: It is a fair , warm summer morning , and the sun shines on them , as they walk towards the darkening mist that overspreads the City .

Parsing [sent. 16312 len. 82]: Gradually they come into the darker , narrower streets , where the sun , now yellow , and now red , is seen through the mist , only at street corners , and in small open spaces where there is a tree , or one of the innumerable churches , or a paved way and a flight of steps , or a curious little patch of garden , or a burying-ground , where the few tombs and tombstones are almost black .

Parsing [sent. 16434 len. 3]: CHAPTER 58 .
Parsing [sent. 16435 len. 15]: After a Lapse The sea had ebbed and flowed , through a whole year .
Parsing [sent. 16436 len. 28]: Through a whole year , the winds and clouds had come and gone ; the ceaseless work of Time had been performed , in storm and sunshine .
Parsing [sent. 16437 len. 19]: Through a whole year , the tides of human chance and change had set in their allotted courses .
Parsing [sent. 16438 len. 85]: Through a whole year , the famous House of Dombey and Son had fought a fight for life , against cross accidents , doubtful rumours , unsuccessful ventures , unpropitious times , and most of all , against the infatuation of its head , who would not contract its enterprises by a hair 's breadth , and would not listen to a word of warning that the ship he strained so hard against the storm , was weak , and could not bear it .
Parsing [sent. 16439 len. 12]: The year was out , and the great House was down .
Parsing [sent. 16440 len. 34]: One summer afternoon ; a year , wanting some odd days , after the marriage in the City church ; there was a buzz and whisper upon ` Change of a great failure .
Parsing [sent. 16441 len. 20]: A certain cold proud man , well known there , was not there , nor was he represented there .
Parsing [sent. 16442 len. 29]: Next day it was noised abroad that Dombey and Son had stopped , and next night there was a List of Bankrupts published , headed by that name .
Parsing [sent. 16443 len. 17]: The world was very busy now , in sooth , and had a deal to say .
Parsing [sent. 16444 len. 11]: It was an innocently credulous and a much ill-used world .
Parsing [sent. 16445 len. 16]: It was a world in which there was ` no other sort of bankruptcy whatever .
Parsing [sent. 16446 len. 24]: There were no conspicuous people in it , trading far and wide on rotten banks of religion , patriotism , virtue , honour .
Parsing [sent. 16447 len. 30]: There was no amount worth mentioning of mere paper in circulation , on which anybody lived pretty handsomely , promising to pay great sums of goodness with no effects .
Parsing [sent. 16448 len. 11]: There were no shortcomings anywhere , in anything but money .
Parsing [sent. 16449 len. 40]: The world was very angry indeed ; and the people especially , who , in a worse world , might have been supposed to be apt traders themselves in shows and pretences , were observed to be mightily indignant .
Parsing [sent. 16450 len. 20]: Here was a new inducement to dissipation , presented to that sport of circumstances , Mr Perch the Messenger !
Parsing [sent. 16451 len. 19]: It was apparently the fate of Mr Perch to be always waking up , and finding himself famous .
Parsing [sent. 16452 len. 43]: He had but yesterday , as one might say , subsided into private life from the celebrity of the elopement and the events that followed it ; and now he was made a more important man than ever , by the bankruptcy .
Parsing [sent. 16453 len. 80]: Gliding from his bracket in the outer office where he now sat , watching the strange faces of accountants and others , who quickly superseded nearly all the old clerks , Mr Perch had but to show himself in the court outside , or , at farthest , in the bar of the King 's Arms , to be asked a multitude of questions , almost certain to include that interesting question , what would he take to drink ?
Parsing [sent. 16454 len. 33]: Then would Mr Perch descant upon the hours of acute uneasiness he and Mrs Perch had suffered out at Balls Pond , when they first suspected ` things was going wrong . '
Parsing [sent. 16455 len. 70]: Then would Mr Perch relate to gaping listeners , in a low voice , as if the corpse of the deceased House were lying unburied in the next room , how Mrs Perch had first come to surmise that things was going wrong by hearing him -LRB- Perch -RRB- moaning in his sleep , ` twelve and ninepence in the pound , twelve and ninepence in the pound ! '
Parsing [sent. 16456 len. 24]: Which act of somnambulism he supposed to have originated in the impression made upon him by the change in Mr Dombey 's face .
Parsing [sent. 16457 len. 30]: Then would he inform them how he had once said , ` Might I make so bold as ask , Sir , are you unhappy in your mind ? '
Parsing [sent. 16458 len. 21]: and how Mr Dombey had replied , ` My faithful Perch -- but no , it can not be ! '
Parsing [sent. 16459 len. 21]: and with that had struck his hand upon his forehead , and said , ` Leave me , Perch ! '
Parsing [sent. 16460 len. 55]: Then , in short , would Mr Perch , a victim to his position , tell all manner of lies ; affecting himself to tears by those that were of a moving nature , and really believing that the inventions of yesterday had , on repetition , a sort of truth about them to-day .
Parsing [sent. 16461 len. 31]: Mr Perch always closed these conferences by meekly remarking , That , of course , whatever his suspicions might have been -LRB- as if he had ever had any ! -RRB-
Parsing [sent. 16462 len. 13]: it was n't for him to betray his trust , was it ?
Parsing [sent. 16463 len. 20]: Which sentiment -LRB- there never being any creditors present -RRB- was received as doing great honour to his feelings .
Parsing [sent. 16464 len. 129]: Thus , he generally brought away a soothed conscience and left an agreeable impression behind him , when he returned to his bracket : again to sit watching the strange faces of the accountants and others , making so free with the great mysteries , the Books ; or now and then to go on tiptoe into Mr Dombey 's empty room , and stir the fire ; or to take an airing at the door , and have a little more doleful chat with any straggler whom he knew ; or to propitiate , with various small attentions , the head accountant : from whom Mr Perch had expectations of a messengership in a Fire Office , when the affairs of the House should be wound up .

Parsing [sent. 16676 len. 98]: The old woman , whose wits appeared disorderly by alarm , remorse , or grief , came creeping along the side of the bed , opposite to that on which Harriet sat ; and kneeling down , so as to bring her withered face upon a level with the coverlet , and stretching out her hand , so as to touch her daughter 's arm , began : ` My handsome gal -- ' Heaven , what a cry was that , with which she stopped there , gazing at the poor form lying on the bed !

Parsing [sent. 16824 len. 74]: The men in the carpet caps go on tumbling the furniture about ; and the gentlemen with the pens and ink make out inventories of it , and sit upon pieces of furniture never made to be sat upon , and eat bread and cheese from the public-house on other pieces of furniture never made to be eaten on , and seem to have a delight in appropriating precious articles to strange uses .
Parsing [sent. 16825 len. 8]: Chaotic combinations of furniture also take place .
Parsing [sent. 16826 len. 48]: Mattresses and bedding appear in the dining-room ; the glass and china get into the conservatory ; the great dinner service is set out in heaps on the long divan in the large drawing-room ; and the stair-wires , made into fasces , decorate the marble chimneypieces .
Parsing [sent. 16827 len. 31]: Finally , a rug , with a printed bill upon it , is hung out from the balcony ; and a similar appendage graces either side of the hall door .
Parsing [sent. 16828 len. 111]: Then , all day long , there is a retinue of mouldy gigs and chaise-carts in the street ; and herds of shabby vampires , Jew and Christian , over-run the house , sounding the plate-glass minors with their knuckles , striking discordant octaves on the Grand Piano , drawing wet forefingers over the pictures , breathing on the blades of the best dinner-knives , punching the squabs of chairs and sofas with their dirty fists , touzling the feather beds , opening and shutting all the drawers , balancing the silver spoons and forks , looking into the very threads of the drapery and linen , and disparaging everything .
Parsing [sent. 16829 len. 11]: There is not a secret place in the whole house .
Parsing [sent. 16830 len. 16]: Fluffy and snuffy strangers stare into the kitchen-range as curiously as into the attic clothes-press .
Parsing [sent. 16831 len. 23]: Stout men with napless hats on , look out of the bedroom windows , and cut jokes with friends in the street .
Parsing [sent. 16832 len. 22]: Quiet , calculating spirits withdraw into the dressing-rooms with catalogues , and make marginal notes thereon , with stumps of pencils .
Parsing [sent. 16833 len. 22]: Two brokers invade the very fire-escape , and take a panoramic survey of the neighbourhood from the top of the house .
Parsing [sent. 16834 len. 15]: The swarm and buzz , and going up and down , endure for days .
Parsing [sent. 16835 len. 13]: The Capital Modern Household Furniture , & c. , is on view .
Parsing [sent. 16836 len. 84]: Then there is a palisade of tables made in the best drawing-room ; and on the capital , french-polished , extending , telescopic range of Spanish mahogany dining-tables with turned legs , the pulpit of the Auctioneer is erected ; and the herds of shabby vampires , Jew and Christian , the strangers fluffy and snuffy , and the stout men with the napless hats , congregate about it and sit upon everything within reach , mantel-pieces included , and begin to bid .
Parsing [sent. 16837 len. 42]: Hot , humming , and dusty are the rooms all day ; and -- high above the heat , hum , and dust -- the head and shoulders , voice and hammer , of the Auctioneer , are ever at work .

Parsing [sent. 16840 len. 9]: This lasts all day and three days following .
Parsing [sent. 16841 len. 13]: The Capital Modern Household Furniture , & c. , is on sale .
Parsing [sent. 16842 len. 24]: Then the mouldy gigs and chaise-carts reappear ; and with them come spring-vans and waggons , and an army of porters with knots .
Parsing [sent. 16843 len. 53]: All day long , the men with carpet caps are screwing at screw-drivers and bed-winches , or staggering by the dozen together on the staircase under heavy burdens , or upheaving perfect rocks of Spanish mahogany , best rose-wood , or plate-glass , into the gigs and chaise-carts , vans and waggons .

Parsing [sent. 16847 len. 7]: At last it is all gone .

Parsing [sent. 16851 len. 11]: At length he follows the men with the carpet caps .

Parsing [sent. 16853 len. 13]: The house is a ruin , and the rats fly from it .
Parsing [sent. 16854 len. 28]: Mrs Pipchin 's apartments , together with those locked rooms on the ground-floor where the window-blinds are drawn down close , have been spared the general devastation .
Parsing [sent. 16855 len. 41]: Mrs Pipchin has remained austere and stony during the proceedings , in her own room ; or has occasionally looked in at the sale to see what the goods are fetching , and to bid for one particular easy chair .
Parsing [sent. 16856 len. 25]: Mrs Pipchin has been the highest bidder for the easy chair , and sits upon her property when Mrs Chick comes to see her .
Parsing [sent. 16857 len. 10]: ` How is my brother , Mrs Pipchin ? '
Parsing [sent. 16858 len. 5]: says Mrs Chick . '
Parsing [sent. 16859 len. 15]: I do n't know any more than the deuce , ' says Mrs Pipchin .
Parsing [sent. 16860 len. 12]: ` He never does me the honour to speak to me .
Parsing [sent. 16861 len. 31]: He has his meat and drink put in the next room to his own ; and what he takes , he comes out and takes when there 's nobody there .
Parsing [sent. 16862 len. 7]: It 's no use asking me .
Parsing [sent. 16863 len. 23]: I know no more about him than the man in the south who burnt his mouth by eating cold plum porridge . ''
Parsing [sent. 16864 len. 9]: This the acrimonious Pipchin says with a flounce .

Parsing [sent. 16866 len. 5]: cries Mrs Chick blandly .

Parsing [sent. 16875 len. 7]: I 'm sure I have ! '

Parsing [sent. 16879 len. 5]: Why , my gracious !

Parsing [sent. 16896 len. 3]: Very good .

Parsing [sent. 16944 len. 86]: Mrs Pipchin by this time looms dark in her black bombazeen skirts , black bonnet , and shawl ; and has her personal property packed up ; and has her chair -LRB- late a favourite chair of Mr Dombey 's and the dead bargain of the sale -RRB- ready near the street door ; and is only waiting for a fly-van , going to-night to Brighton on private service , which is to call for her , by private contract , and convey her home .
Parsing [sent. 16945 len. 4]: Presently it comes .

Parsing [sent. 16950 len. 19]: The house is such a ruin that the rats have fled , and there is not one left .
Parsing [sent. 16951 len. 33]: But Polly , though alone in the deserted mansion -- for there is no companionship in the shut-up rooms in which its late master hides his head -- is not alone long .
Parsing [sent. 16952 len. 60]: It is night ; and she is sitting at work in the housekeeper 's room , trying to forget what a lonely house it is , and what a history belongs to it ; when there is a knock at the hall door , as loud sounding as any knock can be , striking into such an empty place .
Parsing [sent. 16953 len. 21]: Opening it , she returns across the echoing hall , accompanied by a female figure in a close black bonnet .
Parsing [sent. 16954 len. 13]: It is Miss Tox , and Miss Tox 's eyes are red .

Parsing [sent. 16966 len. 11]: He must be very bad there , poor gentleman ! '
Parsing [sent. 16967 len. 12]: Miss Tox 's sympathy is such that she can scarcely speak .
Parsing [sent. 16968 len. 16]: She is no chicken , but she has not grown tough with age and celibacy .
Parsing [sent. 16969 len. 16]: Her heart is very tender , her compassion very genuine , her homage very real .
Parsing [sent. 16970 len. 51]: Beneath the locket with the fishy eye in it , Miss Tox bears better qualities than many a less whimsical outside ; such qualities as will outlive , by many courses of the sun , the best outsides and brightest husks that fall in the harvest of the great reaper .
Parsing [sent. 16971 len. 62]: It is long before Miss Tox goes away , and before Polly , with a candle flaring on the blank stairs , looks after her , for company , down the street , and feels unwilling to go back into the dreary house , and jar its emptiness with the heavy fastenings of the door , and glide away to bed .
Parsing [sent. 16972 len. 43]: But all this Polly does ; and in the morning sets in one of those darkened rooms such matters as she has been advised to prepare , and then retires and enters them no more until next morning at the same hour .
Parsing [sent. 16973 len. 28]: There are bells there , but they never ring ; and though she can sometimes hear a footfall going to and fro , it never comes out .
Parsing [sent. 16974 len. 8]: Miss Tox returns early in the day .
Parsing [sent. 16975 len. 30]: It then begins to be Miss Tox 's occupation to prepare little dainties -- or what are such to her -- to be carried into these rooms next morning .
Parsing [sent. 16976 len. 46]: She derives so much satisfaction from the pursuit , that she enters on it regularly from that time ; and brings daily in her little basket , various choice condiments selected from the scanty stores of the deceased owner of the powdered head and pigtail .
Parsing [sent. 16977 len. 97]: She likewise brings , in sheets of curl-paper , morsels of cold meats , tongues of sheep , halves of fowls , for her own dinner ; and sharing these collations with Polly , passes the greater part of her time in the ruined house that the rats have fled from : hiding , in a fright at every sound , stealing in and out like a criminal ; only desiring to be true to the fallen object of her admiration , unknown to him , unknown to all the world but one poor simple woman .
Parsing [sent. 16978 len. 22]: The Major knows it ; but no one is the wiser for that , though the Major is much the merrier .
Parsing [sent. 16979 len. 27]: The Major , in a fit of curiosity , has charged the Native to watch the house sometimes , and find out what becomes of Dombey .
Parsing [sent. 16980 len. 20]: The Native has reported Miss Tox 's fidelity , and the Major has nearly choked himself dead with laughter .

Parsing [sent. 16982 len. 5]: And the ruined man .
Parsing [sent. 16983 len. 9]: How does he pass the hours , alone ?

Parsing [sent. 16999 len. 12]: He was fallen , never to be raised up any more .
Parsing [sent. 17000 len. 40]: For the night of his worldly ruin there was no to-morrow 's sun ; for the stain of his domestic shame there was no purification ; nothing , thank Heaven , could bring his dead child back to life .
Parsing [sent. 17001 len. 74]: But that which he might have made so different in all the Past -- which might have made the Past itself so different , though this he hardly thought of now -- that which was his own work , that which he could so easily have wrought into a blessing , and had set himself so steadily for years to form into a curse : that was the sharp grief of his soul .
Parsing [sent. 17002 len. 2]: Oh !
Parsing [sent. 17003 len. 5]: He did remember it !
Parsing [sent. 17004 len. 26]: The rain that fell upon the roof , the wind that mourned outside the door that night , had had foreknowledge in their melancholy sound .
Parsing [sent. 17005 len. 10]: He knew , now , what he had done .
Parsing [sent. 17006 len. 26]: He knew , now , that he had called down that upon his head , which bowed it lower than the heaviest stroke of fortune .
Parsing [sent. 17007 len. 37]: He knew , now , what it was to be rejected and deserted ; now , when every loving blossom he had withered in his innocent daughter 's heart was snowing down in ashes on him .
Parsing [sent. 17008 len. 19]: He thought of her , as she had been that night when he and his bride came home .
Parsing [sent. 17009 len. 18]: He thought of her as she had been , in all the home-events of the abandoned house .
Parsing [sent. 17010 len. 17]: He thought , now , that of all around him , she alone had never changed .
Parsing [sent. 17011 len. 62]: His boy had faded into dust , his proud wife had sunk into a polluted creature , his flatterer and friend had been transformed into the worst of villains , his riches had melted away , the very walls that sheltered him looked on him as a stranger ; she alone had turned the same mild gentle look upon him always .
Parsing [sent. 17012 len. 9]: Yes , to the latest and the last .
Parsing [sent. 17013 len. 20]: She had never changed to him -- nor had he ever changed to her -- and she was lost .
Parsing [sent. 17014 len. 46]: As , one by one , they fell away before his mind -- his baby-hope , his wife , his friend , his fortune -- oh how the mist , through which he had seen her , cleared , and showed him her true self !
Parsing [sent. 17015 len. 36]: Oh , how much better than this that he had loved her as he had his boy , and lost her as he had his boy , and laid them in their early grave together !
Parsing [sent. 17016 len. 19]: In his pride -- for he was proud yet -- he let the world go from him freely .
Parsing [sent. 17017 len. 10]: As it fell away , he shook it off .
Parsing [sent. 17018 len. 21]: Whether he imagined its face as expressing pity for him , or indifference to him , he shunned it alike .
Parsing [sent. 17019 len. 14]: It was in the same degree to be avoided , in either aspect .
Parsing [sent. 17020 len. 20]: He had no idea of any one companion in his misery , but the one he had driven away .
Parsing [sent. 17021 len. 23]: What he would have said to her , or what consolation submitted to receive from her , he never pictured to himself .
Parsing [sent. 17022 len. 18]: But he always knew she would have been true to him , if he had suffered her .
Parsing [sent. 17023 len. 54]: He always knew she would have loved him better now , than at any other time ; he was as certain that it was in her nature , as he was that there was a sky above him ; and he sat thinking so , in his loneliness , from hour to hour .
Parsing [sent. 17024 len. 15]: Day after day uttered this speech ; night after night showed him this knowledge .
Parsing [sent. 17025 len. 34]: It began , beyond all doubt -LRB- however slow it advanced for some time -RRB- , in the receipt of her young husband 's letter , and the certainty that she was gone .
Parsing [sent. 17026 len. 52]: And yet -- so proud he was in his ruin , or so reminiscent of her only as something that might have been his , but was lost beyond redemption -- that if he could have heard her voice in an adjoining room , he would not have gone to her .
Parsing [sent. 17027 len. 58]: If he could have seen her in the street , and she had done no more than look at him as she had been used to look , he would have passed on with his old cold unforgiving face , and not addressed her , or relaxed it , though his heart should have broken soon afterwards .
Parsing [sent. 17028 len. 29]: However turbulent his thoughts , or harsh his anger had been , at first , concerning her marriage , or her husband , that was all past now .
Parsing [sent. 17029 len. 14]: He chiefly thought of what might have been , and what was not .
Parsing [sent. 17030 len. 24]: What was , was all summed up in this : that she was lost , and he bowed down with sorrow and remorse .
Parsing [sent. 17031 len. 51]: And now he felt that he had had two children born to him in that house , and that between him and the bare wide empty walls there was a tie , mournful , but hard to rend asunder , connected with a double childhood , and a double loss .
Parsing [sent. 17032 len. 54]: He had thought to leave the house -- knowing he must go , not knowing whither -- upon the evening of the day on which this feeling first struck root in his breast ; but he resolved to stay another night , and in the night to ramble through the rooms once more .
Parsing [sent. 17033 len. 27]: He came out of his solitude when it was the dead of night , and with a candle in his hand went softly up the stairs .
Parsing [sent. 17034 len. 43]: Of all the footmarks there , making them as common as the common street , there was not one , he thought , but had seemed at the time to set itself upon his brain while he had kept close , listening .
Parsing [sent. 17035 len. 57]: He looked at their number , and their hurry , and contention -- foot treading foot out , and upward track and downward jostling one another -- and thought , with absolute dread and wonder , how much he must have suffered during that trial , and what a changed man he had cause to be .
Parsing [sent. 17036 len. 29]: He thought , besides , oh was there , somewhere in the world , a light footstep that might have worn out in a moment half those marks !
Parsing [sent. 17037 len. 13]: -- and bent his head , and wept as he went up .
Parsing [sent. 17038 len. 9]: He almost saw it , going on before .
Parsing [sent. 17039 len. 33]: He stopped , looking up towards the skylight ; and a figure , childish itself , but carrying a child , and singing as it went , seemed to be there again .
Parsing [sent. 17040 len. 35]: Anon , it was the same figure , alone , stopping for an instant , with suspended breath ; the bright hair clustering loosely round its tearful face ; and looking back at him .
Parsing [sent. 17041 len. 28]: He wandered through the rooms : lately so luxurious ; now so bare and dismal and so changed , apparently , even in their shape and size .
Parsing [sent. 17042 len. 25]: The press of footsteps was as thick here ; and the same consideration of the suffering he had had , perplexed and terrified him .
Parsing [sent. 17043 len. 48]: He began to fear that all this intricacy in his brain would drive him mad ; and that his thoughts already lost coherence as the footprints did , and were pieced on to one another , with the same trackless involutions , and varieties of indistinct shapes .
Parsing [sent. 17044 len. 21]: He did not so much as know in which of these rooms she had lived , when she was alone .
Parsing [sent. 17045 len. 13]: He was glad to leave them , and go wandering higher up .
Parsing [sent. 17046 len. 45]: Abundance of associations were here , connected with his false wife , his false friend and servant , his false grounds of pride ; but he put them all by now , and only recalled miserably , weakly , fondly , his two children .
Parsing [sent. 17047 len. 5]: Everywhere , the footsteps !
Parsing [sent. 17048 len. 54]: They had had no respect for the old room high up , where the little bed had been ; he could hardly find a clear space there , to throw himself down , on the floor , against the wall , poor broken man , and let his tears flow as they would .
Parsing [sent. 17049 len. 42]: He had shed so many tears here , long ago , that he was less ashamed of his weakness in this place than in any other -- perhaps , with that consciousness , had made excuses to himself for coming here .
Parsing [sent. 17050 len. 18]: Here , with stooping shoulders , and his chin dropped on his breast , he had come .
Parsing [sent. 17051 len. 63]: Here , thrown upon the bare boards , in the dead of night , he wept , alone -- a proud man , even then ; who , if a kind hand could have been stretched out , or a kind face could have looked in , would have risen up , and turned away , and gone down to his cell .
Parsing [sent. 17052 len. 13]: When the day broke he was shut up in his rooms again .
Parsing [sent. 17053 len. 26]: He had meant to go away to-day , but clung to this tie in the house as the last and only thing left to him .

Parsing [sent. 17055 len. 3]: To-morrow came .
Parsing [sent. 17056 len. 5]: He would go to-morrow .
Parsing [sent. 17057 len. 25]: Every night , within the knowledge of no human creature , he came forth , and wandered through the despoiled house like a ghost .
Parsing [sent. 17058 len. 38]: Many a morning when the day broke , his altered face , drooping behind the closed blind in his window , imperfectly transparent to the light as yet , pondered on the loss of his two children .
Parsing [sent. 17059 len. 7]: It was one child no more .
Parsing [sent. 17060 len. 13]: He reunited them in his thoughts , and they were never asunder .
Parsing [sent. 17061 len. 29]: Oh , that he could have united them in his past love , and in death , and that one had not been so much worse than dead !
Parsing [sent. 17062 len. 17]: Strong mental agitation and disturbance was no novelty to him , even before his late sufferings .
Parsing [sent. 17063 len. 18]: It never is , to obstinate and sullen natures ; for they struggle hard to be such .

Parsing [sent. 17065 len. 13]: At last he began to think he need not go at all .

Parsing [sent. 17067 len. 10]: The world was very busy and restless about him .
Parsing [sent. 17068 len. 7]: He became aware of that again .
Parsing [sent. 17069 len. 6]: It was whispering and babbling .
Parsing [sent. 17070 len. 5]: It was never quiet .
Parsing [sent. 17071 len. 16]: This , and the intricacy and complication of the footsteps , harassed him to death .
Parsing [sent. 17072 len. 13]: Objects began to take a bleared and russet colour in his eyes .
Parsing [sent. 17073 len. 12]: Dombey and Son was no more -- his children no more .
Parsing [sent. 17074 len. 10]: This must be thought of , well , to-morrow .
Parsing [sent. 17075 len. 44]: He thought of it to-morrow ; and sitting thinking in his chair , saw in the glass , from time to time , this picture : A spectral , haggard , wasted likeness of himself , brooded and brooded over the empty fireplace .
Parsing [sent. 17076 len. 26]: Now it lifted up its head , examining the lines and hollows in its face ; now hung it down again , and brooded afresh .

Parsing [sent. 17182 len. 92]: Chiefly Matrimonial The grand half-yearly festival holden by Doctor and Mrs Blimber , on which occasion they requested the pleasure of the company of every young gentleman pursuing his studies in that genteel establishment , at an early party , when the hour was half-past seven o'clock , and when the object was quadrilles , had duly taken place , about this time ; and the young gentlemen , with no unbecoming demonstrations of levity , had betaken themselves , in a state of scholastic repletion , to their own homes .

Parsing [sent. 17186 len. 76]: Master Bitherstone now , on whom the forcing system had the happier and not uncommon effect of leaving no impression whatever , when the forcing apparatus ceased to work , was in a much more comfortable plight ; and being then on shipboard , bound for Bengal , found himself forgetting , with such admirable rapidity , that it was doubtful whether his declensions of noun-substantives would hold out to the end of the voyage .

Parsing [sent. 17285 len. 116]: Shortly after which , as the Doctor 's eyes were twinkling in a remarkable manner , and his son-in-law had already observed that time was made for slaves , and had inquired whether Mrs Toots sang , the discreet Mrs Blimber dissolved the sitting , and sent Cornelia away , very cool and comfortable , in a post-chaise , with the man of her heart Mr and Mrs Toots withdrew to the Bedford -LRB- Mrs Toots had been there before in old times , under her maiden name of Nipper -RRB- , and there found a letter , which it took Mr Toots such an enormous time to read , that Mrs Toots was frightened .
Parsing [sent. 17286 len. 17]: ` My dear Susan , ' said Mr Toots , ` fright is worse than exertion .
Parsing [sent. 17287 len. 5]: Pray be calm ! '
Parsing [sent. 17288 len. 7]: ` Who is it from ? '
Parsing [sent. 17289 len. 4]: asked Mrs Toots .

Parsing [sent. 17294 len. 9]: ` She 's a most extraordinary woman ! '
Parsing [sent. 17295 len. 8]: exclaimed Mr Toots , in rapturous admiration .

Parsing [sent. 17297 len. 13]: Miss Dombey has seen her father , and they are reconciled ! '

Parsing [sent. 17300 len. 16]: ` My dear , ' said Mr Toots ; ` pray do not exert yourself .
Parsing [sent. 17301 len. 6]: Do remember the medical man !
Parsing [sent. 17302 len. 72]: Captain Gills says -- at least he do n't say , but I imagine , from what I can make out , he means -- that Miss Dombey has brought her unfortunate father away from his old house , to one where she and Walters are living ; that he is lying very ill there -- supposed to be dying ; and that she attends upon him night and day . '
Parsing [sent. 17303 len. 8]: Mrs Toots began to cry quite bitterly .
Parsing [sent. 17304 len. 25]: ` My dearest Susan , ' replied Mr Toots , ` do , do , if you possibly can , remember the medical man !
Parsing [sent. 17305 len. 17]: If you ca n't , it 's of no consequence -- but do endeavour to ! '
Parsing [sent. 17306 len. 74]: His wife , with her old manner suddenly restored , so pathetically entreated him to take her to her precious pet , her little mistress , her own darling , and the like , that Mr Toots , whose sympathy and admiration were of the strongest kind , consented from his very heart of hearts ; and they agreed to depart immediately , and present themselves in answer to the Captain 's letter .
Parsing [sent. 17307 len. 46]: Now some hidden sympathies of things , or some coincidences , had that day brought the Captain himself -LRB- toward whom Mr and Mrs Toots were soon journeying -RRB- into the flowery train of wedlock ; not as a principal , but as an accessory .
Parsing [sent. 17308 len. 85]: It happened accidentally , and thus : The Captain , having seen Florence and her baby for a moment , to his unbounded content , and having had a long talk with Walter , turned out for a walk ; feeling it necessary to have some solitary meditation on the changes of human affairs , and to shake his glazed hat profoundly over the fall of Mr Dombey , for whom the generosity and simplicity of his nature were awakened in a lively manner .
Parsing [sent. 17309 len. 79]: The Captain would have been very low , indeed , on the unhappy gentleman 's account , but for the recollection of the baby ; which afforded him such intense satisfaction whenever it arose , that he laughed aloud as he went along the street , and , indeed , more than once , in a sudden impulse of joy , threw up his glazed hat and caught it again ; much to the amazement of the spectators .
Parsing [sent. 17310 len. 97]: The rapid alternations of light and shade to which these two conflicting subjects of reflection exposed the Captain , were so very trying to his spirits , that he felt a long walk necessary to his composure ; and as there is a great deal in the influence of harmonious associations , he chose , for the scene of this walk , his old neighbourhood , down among the mast , oar , and block makers , ship-biscuit bakers , coal-whippers , pitch-kettles , sailors , canals , docks , swing-bridges , and other soothing objects .
Parsing [sent. 17311 len. 75]: These peaceful scenes , and particularly the region of Limehouse Hole and thereabouts , were so influential in calming the Captain , that he walked on with restored tranquillity , and was , in fact , regaling himself , under his breath , with the ballad of Lovely Peg , when , on turning a corner , he was suddenly transfixed and rendered speechless by a triumphant procession that he beheld advancing towards him .
Parsing [sent. 17312 len. 83]: This awful demonstration was headed by that determined woman Mrs MacStinger , who , preserving a countenance of inexorable resolution , and wearing conspicuously attached to her obdurate bosom a stupendous watch and appendages , which the Captain recognised at a glance as the property of Bunsby , conducted under her arm no other than that sagacious mariner ; he , with the distraught and melancholy visage of a captive borne into a foreign land , meekly resigning himself to her will .
Parsing [sent. 17313 len. 13]: Behind them appeared the young MacStingers , in a body , exulting .
Parsing [sent. 17314 len. 29]: Behind them , M ~ two ladies of a terrible and steadfast aspect , leading between them a short gentleman in a tall hat , who likewise exulted .
Parsing [sent. 17315 len. 12]: In the wake , appeared Bunsby 's boy , bearing umbrellas .
Parsing [sent. 17316 len. 47]: The whole were in good marching order ; and a dreadful smartness that pervaded the party would have sufficiently announced , if the intrepid countenances of the ladies had been wanting , that it was a procession of sacrifice , and that the victim was Bunsby .
Parsing [sent. 17317 len. 11]: The first impulse of the Captain was to run away .
Parsing [sent. 17318 len. 19]: This also appeared to be the first impulse of Bunsby , hopeless as its execution must have proved .
Parsing [sent. 17319 len. 26]: But a cry of recognition proceeding from the party , and Alexander MacStinger running up to the Captain with open arms , the Captain struck .
Parsing [sent. 17320 len. 9]: ` Well , Cap ` en Cuttle ! '
Parsing [sent. 17321 len. 4]: said Mrs MacStinger .
Parsing [sent. 17322 len. 7]: ` This is indeed a meeting !
Parsing [sent. 17323 len. 25]: I bear no malice now , Cap ` en Cuttle -- you need n't fear that I 'm a going to cast any reflections .
Parsing [sent. 17324 len. 12]: I hope to go to the altar in another spirit . '
Parsing [sent. 17325 len. 38]: Here Mrs MacStinger paused , and drawing herself up , and inflating her bosom with a long breath , said , in allusion to the victim , ` My ` usband , Cap ` en Cuttle ! '
Parsing [sent. 17326 len. 30]: The abject Bunsby looked neither to the right nor to the left , nor at his bride , nor at his friend , but straight before him at nothing .
Parsing [sent. 17327 len. 26]: The Captain putting out his hand , Bunsby put out his ; but , in answer to the Captain 's greeting , spake no word .
Parsing [sent. 17328 len. 51]: ` Cap ` en Cuttle , ' said Mrs MacStinger , ` if you would wish to heal up past animosities , and to see the last of your friend , my ` usband , as a single person , we should be ` appy of your company to chapel .
Parsing [sent. 17329 len. 39]: Here is a lady here , ' said Mrs MacStinger , turning round to the more intrepid of the two , ` my bridesmaid , that will be glad of your protection , Cap ` en Cuttle . '
Parsing [sent. 17330 len. 48]: The short gentleman in the tall hat , who it appeared was the husband of the other lady , and who evidently exulted at the reduction of a fellow creature to his own condition , gave place at this , and resigned the lady to Captain Cuttle .
Parsing [sent. 17331 len. 29]: The lady immediately seized him , and , observing that there was no time to lose , gave the word , in a strong voice , to advance .
Parsing [sent. 17332 len. 123]: The Captain 's concern for his friend , not unmingled , at first , with some concern for himself -- for a shadowy terror that he might be married by violence , possessed him , until his knowledge of the service came to his relief , and remembering the legal obligation of saying , ' I will , ' he felt himself personally safe so long as he resolved , if asked any question , distinctly to reply I wo n't ' -- threw him into a profuse perspiration ; and rendered him , for a time , insensible to the movements of the procession , of which he now formed a feature , and to the conversation of his fair companion .
Parsing [sent. 17333 len. 110]: But as he became less agitated , he learnt from this lady that she was the widow of a Mr Bokum , who had held an employment in the Custom House ; that she was the dearest friend of Mrs MacStinger , whom she considered a pattern for her sex ; that she had often heard of the Captain , and now hoped he had repented of his past life ; that she trusted Mr Bunsby knew what a blessing he had gained , but that she feared men seldom did know what such blessings were , until they had lost them ; with more to the same purpose .
Parsing [sent. 17334 len. 53]: All this time , the Captain could not but observe that Mrs Bokum kept her eyes steadily on the bridegroom , and that whenever they came near a court or other narrow turning which appeared favourable for flight , she was on the alert to cut him off if he attempted escape .
Parsing [sent. 17335 len. 53]: The other lady , too , as well as her husband , the short gentleman with the tall hat , were plainly on guard , according to a preconcerted plan ; and the wretched man was so secured by Mrs MacStinger , that any effort at self-preservation by flight was rendered futile .
Parsing [sent. 17336 len. 45]: This , indeed , was apparent to the mere populace , who expressed their perception of the fact by jeers and cries ; to all of which , the dread MacStinger was inflexibly indifferent , while Bunsby himself appeared in a state of unconsciousness .
Parsing [sent. 17337 len. 58]: The Captain made many attempts to accost the philosopher , if only in a monosyllable or a signal ; but always failed , in consequence of the vigilance of the guard , and the difficulty , at all times peculiar to Bunsby 's constitution , of having his attention aroused by any outward and visible sign whatever .
Parsing [sent. 17338 len. 52]: Thus they approached the chapel , a neat whitewashed edifice , recently engaged by the Reverend Melchisedech Howler , who had consented , on very urgent solicitation , to give the world another two years of existence , but had informed his followers that , then , it must positively go .
Parsing [sent. 17339 len. 35]: While the Reverend Melchisedech was offering up some extemporary orisons , the Captain found an opportunity of growling in the bridegroom 's ear : ` What cheer , my lad , what cheer ? '
Parsing [sent. 17340 len. 54]: To which Bunsby replied , with a forgetfulness of the Reverend Melchisedech , which nothing but his desperate circumstances could have excused : 'D -- -- - d bad , ' ` Jack Bunsby , ' whispered the Captain , ` do you do this here , of your own free will ? '
Parsing [sent. 17341 len. 7]: Mr Bunsby answered ` No . '

Parsing [sent. 17344 len. 25]: Bunsby , still looking , and always looking with an immovable countenance , at the opposite side of the world , made no reply .

Parsing [sent. 17378 len. 5]: Now or never ! '
Parsing [sent. 17379 len. 18]: Bunsby did n't then , and did n't ever ; for Mrs MacStinger immediately afterwards married him .
Parsing [sent. 17380 len. 49]: One of the most frightful circumstances of the ceremony to the Captain , was the deadly interest exhibited therein by Juliana MacStinger ; and the fatal concentration of her faculties , with which that promising child , already the image of her parent , observed the whole proceedings .
Parsing [sent. 17381 len. 30]: The Captain saw in this a succession of man-traps stretching out infinitely ; a series of ages of oppression and coercion , through which the seafaring line was doomed .
Parsing [sent. 17382 len. 38]: It was a more memorable sight than the unflinching steadiness of Mrs Bokum and the other lady , the exultation of the short gentleman in the tall hat , or even the fell inflexibility of Mrs MacStinger .
Parsing [sent. 17383 len. 50]: The Master MacStingers understood little of what was going on , and cared less ; being chiefly engaged , during the ceremony , in treading on one another 's half-boots ; but the contrast afforded by those wretched infants only set off and adorned the precocious woman in Juliana .
Parsing [sent. 17384 len. 21]: Another year or two , the Captain thought , and to lodge where that child was , would be destruction .
Parsing [sent. 17385 len. 33]: The ceremony was concluded by a general spring of the young family on Mr Bunsby , whom they hailed by the endearing name of father , and from whom they solicited half-pence .
Parsing [sent. 17386 len. 34]: These gushes of affection over , the procession was about to issue forth again , when it was delayed for some little time by an unexpected transport on the part of Alexander MacStinger .
Parsing [sent. 17387 len. 49]: That dear child , it seemed , connecting a chapel with tombstones , when it was entered for any purpose apart from the ordinary religious exercises , could not be persuaded but that his mother was now to be decently interred , and lost to him for ever .
Parsing [sent. 17388 len. 20]: In the anguish of this conviction , he screamed with astonishing force , and turned black in the face .
Parsing [sent. 17389 len. 34]: However touching these marks of a tender disposition were to his mother , it was not in the character of that remarkable woman to permit her recognition of them to degenerate into weakness .
Parsing [sent. 17390 len. 77]: Therefore , after vainly endeavouring to convince his reason by shakes , pokes , bawlings-out , and similar applications to his head , she led him into the air , and tried another method ; which was manifested to the marriage party by a quick succession of sharp sounds , resembling applause , and subsequently , by their seeing Alexander in contact with the coolest paving-stone in the court , greatly flushed , and loudly lamenting .
Parsing [sent. 17391 len. 53]: The procession being then in a condition to form itself once more , and repair to Brig Place , where a marriage feast was in readiness , returned as it had come ; not without the receipt , by Bunsby , of many humorous congratulations from the populace on his recently-acquired happiness .
Parsing [sent. 17392 len. 81]: The Captain accompanied it as far as the house-door , but , being made uneasy by the gentler manner of Mrs Bokum , who , now that she was relieved from her engrossing duty -- for the watchfulness and alacrity of the ladies sensibly diminished when the bridegroom was safely married -- had greater leisure to show an interest in his behalf , there left it and the captive ; faintly pleading an appointment , and promising to return presently .
Parsing [sent. 17393 len. 41]: The Captain had another cause for uneasiness , in remorsefully reflecting that he had been the first means of Bunsby 's entrapment , though certainly without intending it , and through his unbounded faith in the resources of that philosopher .
Parsing [sent. 17394 len. 55]: To go back to old Sol Gills at the wooden Midshipman 's , and not first go round to ask how Mr Dombey was -- albeit the house where he lay was out of London , and away on the borders of a fresh heath -- was quite out of the Captain 's course .
Parsing [sent. 17395 len. 17]: So he got a lift when he was tired , and made out the journey gaily .
Parsing [sent. 17396 len. 48]: The blinds were pulled down , and the house so quiet , that the Captain was almost afraid to knock ; but listening at the door , he heard low voices within , very near it , and , knocking softly , was admitted by Mr Toots .
Parsing [sent. 17397 len. 31]: Mr Toots and his wife had , in fact , just arrived there ; having been at the Midshipman 's to seek him , and having there obtained the address .
Parsing [sent. 17398 len. 36]: They were not so recently arrived , but that Mrs Toots had caught the baby from somebody , taken it in her arms , and sat down on the stairs , hugging and fondling it .
Parsing [sent. 17399 len. 62]: Florence was stooping down beside her ; and no one could have said which Mrs Toots was hugging and fondling most , the mother or the child , or which was the tenderer , Florence of Mrs Toots , or Mrs Toots of her , or both of the baby ; it was such a little group of love and agitation .

Parsing [sent. 17402 len. 12]: ` He is very , very ill , ' said Florence .

Parsing [sent. 17418 len. 3]: CHAPTER 61 .
Parsing [sent. 17419 len. 7]: Relenting Florence had need of help .
Parsing [sent. 17420 len. 19]: Her father 's need of it was sore , and made the aid of her old friend invaluable .
Parsing [sent. 17421 len. 6]: Death stood at his pillow .
Parsing [sent. 17422 len. 45]: A shade , already , of what he had been , shattered in mind , and perilously sick in body , he laid his weary head down on the bed his daughter 's hands prepared for him , and had never raised it since .
Parsing [sent. 17423 len. 6]: She was always with him .
Parsing [sent. 17424 len. 27]: He knew her , generally ; though , in the wandering of his brain , he often confused the circumstances under which he spoke to her .
Parsing [sent. 17425 len. 62]: Thus he would address her , sometimes , as if his boy were newly dead ; and would tell her , that although he had said nothing of her ministering at the little bedside , yet he had seen it -- he had seen it ; and then would hide his face and sob , and put out his worn hand .
Parsing [sent. 17426 len. 8]: Sometimes he would ask her for herself .
Parsing [sent. 17427 len. 7]: ` Where is Florence ? ' '
Parsing [sent. 17428 len. 12]: I am here , Papa , I am here . ' '
Parsing [sent. 17429 len. 7]: I do n't know her ! '
Parsing [sent. 17430 len. 4]: he would cry .
Parsing [sent. 17431 len. 16]: ` We have been parted so long , that I do n't know her ! '
Parsing [sent. 17432 len. 33]: and then a staring dread would he upon him , until she could soothe his perturbation ; and recall the tears she tried so hard , at other times , to dry .
Parsing [sent. 17433 len. 24]: He rambled through the scenes of his old pursuits -- through many where Florence lost him as she listened -- sometimes for hours .
Parsing [sent. 17434 len. 13]: He would repeat that childish question , ` What is money ? '
Parsing [sent. 17435 len. 38]: and ponder on it , and think about it , and reason with himself , more or less connectedly , for a good answer ; as if it had never been proposed to him until that moment .
Parsing [sent. 17436 len. 34]: He would go on with a musing repetition of the title of his old firm twenty thousand times , and at every one of them , would turn his head upon his pillow .
Parsing [sent. 17437 len. 24]: He would count his children -- one - two -- stop , and go back , and begin again in the same way .
Parsing [sent. 17438 len. 13]: But this was when his mind was in its most distracted state .
Parsing [sent. 17439 len. 25]: In all the other phases of its illness , and in those to which it was most constant , it always turned on Florence .
Parsing [sent. 17440 len. 55]: What he would oftenest do was this : he would recall that night he had so recently remembered , the night on which she came down to his room , and would imagine that his heart smote him , and that he went out after her , and up the stairs to seek her .
Parsing [sent. 17441 len. 32]: Then , confounding that time with the later days of the many footsteps , he would be amazed at their number , and begin to count them as he followed her .
Parsing [sent. 17442 len. 52]: Here , of a sudden , was a bloody footstep going on among the others ; and after it there began to be , at intervals , doors standing open , through which certain terrible pictures were seen , in mirrors , of haggard men , concealing something in their breasts .
Parsing [sent. 17443 len. 20]: Still , among the many footsteps and the bloody footsteps here and there , was the step of Florence .
Parsing [sent. 17444 len. 7]: Still she was going on before .
Parsing [sent. 17445 len. 31]: Still the restless mind went , following and counting , ever farther , ever higher , as to the summit of a mighty tower that it took years to climb .
Parsing [sent. 17446 len. 17]: One day he inquired if that were not Susan who had spoken a long while ago .
Parsing [sent. 17447 len. 19]: Florence said ` Yes , dear Papa ; ' and asked him would he like to see her ?
Parsing [sent. 17448 len. 7]: He said ` very much . '
Parsing [sent. 17449 len. 14]: And Susan , with no little trepidation , showed herself at his bedside .
Parsing [sent. 17450 len. 8]: It seemed a great relief to him .
Parsing [sent. 17451 len. 25]: He begged her not to go ; to understand that he forgave her what she had said ; and that she was to stay .
Parsing [sent. 17452 len. 15]: Florence and he were very different now , he said , and very happy .
Parsing [sent. 17453 len. 6]: Let her look at this !
Parsing [sent. 17454 len. 18]: He meant his drawing the gentle head down to his pillow , and laying it beside him .
Parsing [sent. 17455 len. 9]: He remained like this for days and weeks .
Parsing [sent. 17456 len. 42]: At length , lying , the faint feeble semblance of a man , upon his bed , and speaking in a voice so low that they could only hear him by listening very near to his lips , he became quiet .
Parsing [sent. 17457 len. 37]: It was dimly pleasant to him now , to lie there , with the window open , looking out at the summer sky and the trees : and , in the evening , at the sunset .
Parsing [sent. 17458 len. 19]: To watch the shadows of the clouds and leaves , and seem to feel a sympathy with shadows .
Parsing [sent. 17459 len. 7]: It was natural that he should .
Parsing [sent. 17460 len. 11]: To him , life and the world were nothing else .
Parsing [sent. 17461 len. 36]: He began to show now that he thought of Florence 's fatigue : and often taxed his weakness to whisper to her , ` Go and walk , my dearest , in the sweet air .
Parsing [sent. 17462 len. 7]: Go to your good husband ! '
Parsing [sent. 17463 len. 46]: One time when Walter was in his room , he beckoned him to come near , and to stoop down ; and pressing his hand , whispered an assurance to him that he knew he could trust him with his child when he was dead .
Parsing [sent. 17464 len. 107]: It chanced one evening , towards sunset , when Florence and Walter were sitting in his room together , as he liked to see them , that Florence , having her baby in her arms , began in a low voice to sing to the little fellow , and sang the old tune she had so often sung to the dead child : He could not bear it at the time ; he held up his trembling hand , imploring her to stop ; but next day he asked her to repeat it , and to do so often of an evening : which she did .
Parsing [sent. 17465 len. 9]: He listening , with his face turned away .
Parsing [sent. 17466 len. 28]: Florence was sitting on a certain time by his window , with her work-basket between her and her old attendant , who was still her faithful companion .
Parsing [sent. 17467 len. 7]: He had fallen into a doze .
Parsing [sent. 17468 len. 25]: It was a beautiful evening , with two hours of light to come yet ; and the tranquillity and quiet made Florence very thoughtful .

Parsing [sent. 17479 len. 20]: Florence then remembered Cousin Feenix , whom she had not at first recognised in the shade of the leaves .

Parsing [sent. 17481 len. 80]: I could have wished , I am sure , ' said Cousin Feenix , sitting down as Florence sat , to have had an earlier opportunity of offering my congratulations ; but , in point of fact , so many painful occurrences have happened , treading , as a man may say , on one another 's heels , that I have been in a devil of a state myself , and perfectly unfit for every description of society .
